The museum offers a wide selection of Faberge eggs in addition to other handcrafted objects in silver and other jewlery. The muesum seemed like a hidden gem as the que to get in was next to nothing and inside you got the chance to study the objects in peace and quiet without stepping other people. Try it and you wont be disappointed.

Stunning exibits. This is a small museum compared to what you will see in St Petersberg. But as they say good things come in small parcels.This Musume you need to have a guide we had it as part of a two day trip. You have to put overshoes on to visit so make sure you have easy foot ware that won't give you a problem.The stunning exibits are a must for photographs NO FLASH OR STICKS. Make sure you have the guide as it is better to understand the history of the eggs and the other exibits and how they link together. It's problem about 60 to 90 min tour.

Absolute must!. This is a beautiful museum housed in a former palace. The highlights are the 9 Imperial Eggs created by Faberge. I also found the room of Russian paintings exquisite. The room is dimly lit, and the paintings appear to be lit from behind (they are not). They seem to glow. So pretty. We went after 6:30 when we could get the audio guides and do a self-tour. Audio guide is full of information, but also setting around rooms are various language books with information about every single piece in the museum. Fun to look up what some items were even used for. Must put down a deposit for audio guide that you get back upon return.Free lockers near restrooms to store backpacks.Cool restrooms.Nice, varied gift shop.Benches to sit on in various places.Ok to take pictures of items (no flash).

Small but rich. A small museum but a rich collection of Faberge eggs and paintings. The rooms were falsified by colors, which was very original (the red room, the blue room, the gold room...)Quite cute and elegant. Definitely to be seen.

Don't miss this Egg. We did not book before we came but we had a local guide who took us round, if you need her details I will send them to you.With the Faberge they were master craftsman but you must see it if you come to St Petersburg.

Fantastic experience if you're interested in the history and wealth of the Tzars. We did this visit as an organised trip from the P&O Azura but can easily be undertaken by individuals. Lovely building to house the museum - not too busy, plenty of room to move and enjoy the exhibits, audio sets available to assist with explanations and visual experience. The eggs and other exhibits were so intricate and finely made it's no wonder they are worth a fortune. Other rooms in the building contained art and other ornate and 'priceless' items belonging to the Tzars and other wealthy Russians. There is a small gift shop on premises selling a variety of replica eggs and more general items. Well worth a visit. The museum signs say no photography but everyone there was taking photos and videos and none of the numerous and very watchful 'guards' made any move to stop them.

Crowded but worth it.. Long queue to get in even with a guide as the museum is quite small and they limit the number of people inside. The Faberge eggs and other pieces of the jewellers work are amazing. The museum also has lovely pieces of Russian silver and other objets. A must for lovers of such work.

A Gem!. I loved this small museum. Each component of this museum was so interesting and quite easy to navigate on my own. The eggs were so intricate and I now understand why he only made two a year. How fortunate to be a recipient of one of those jewels.The other rooms were done by color which I totally loved.There is also a small well curated gift shop on premises.

Great private collection of the Faberge eggs!. I didn't really know much about the Faberge eggs until visiting here, but it's definitely worth the visit. Make sure you get the audio guide (I was with a tour group) for the explanations about the eggs - they're exquisite! They're truly incredible works of jewellery art. Not to mention all the other items also made by Faberge... :)

Eggs are not eggs!. If you want to see fabulous jewlery and the best collection of Faberge Easter Eggs in the world this is the place to be. The rooms are incredible, take a good look arround each room especially the ceilings and ornate columns. Make sure you get the guide as there is such interesting history behind many items displayed. Not a large museum but there are so many exhibits you should allow a couple of hours or more for the visit. A must see .
visit from a cruise ship. Absolutely fantastic. The Imperial eggs are wonderful works of art but there is so much more in in this small but extraordinary museum. A visit never to be forgotten.

another bucket list item. It goes without saying that this is one of the great Museum in the world. Just go and spend a couple of hours. Wow! Best part for me were not the eggs but the paintings and how they were displayed. What a great city.

Fabulous Faberge. I did not know the history of Faberge but this museum to his works is wonderful. Timed appointments are necessary as only small parties of up to 15 people are allowed at any one time. The rooms are small and to enjoy the exhibits in comfort 15 people is max.
Very nice palace of count Shuvalov. Very good museum and light. Some times I have fill that there are too many exponats in one place. Too many gold ect

Beautiful exquisitely detailed objects everywhere you look!. If you love the decorative arts or beatiful objects the Faberge Museum is a MUST. The collection is housed in the Shuvalov Palace, so each room is lovely, not just the things in it. Several of the Faberge Easter Eggs are here---each one a masterpiece---but there is so much more to enjoy. Faberge made all kinds of things that will take your breath away: personal articles like cigarette cases and opera glasses; drink services; picture frames; miniature objects. You name it, it's all gorgeous. I strongly suggest buying your tickets online ahead of time. We didn't. We stood outside for 40 minutes waiting for the line to creep forward, then we stood in line some more inside. Meanwhile, people who bought online sailed right passed us and into the galleries.

Unreliable lift. I had long wanted to visit this museum to see its wonderful collection of Faberge Eggs. I use a wheelchair and had been forewarned that the lift was unreliable. It therefore came as no surprise but a great disappointment to find that the lift was out of order when I visited. I cannot praise the staff too highly for agreeing to carry me and my wheelchair up and down the staircase so I could see the fantastic exhibits. It was a little hair-raising for both me and the staff but I am immensely grateful for their efforts. I just wonder why, given the millions spent by Viktor Vekselberg and his Foundation on the fabulous eggs, a reliable and working lift has not been installed so the museum is equally open to everyone?

WOW WOW WOW. I was taken to the Faberge Museum by 2 friends who live in St Petersburg. I was blown away. The magnificence of the pieces in the collection .. it is hard to imagine that the fine workmanship was done by highly skilled craftsmen and jewellers in the late 1800's and early 1900'sThe collection of Imperial Easter Eggs is just overwhelming. The Russian Oligarch who founded this magnificent museum reputedly spent $US 100 million for 10 of the Imperial Eggs let alone the other superb pieces in the collection Visitors to St Petersburg must visit this museum plus the others like the Hermitage etc to get an understanding of the opulence of the Royal Court

Eggsquisite!. Loved the Faberge Museum. It was well thought out and interpreted (unlike many places we visited in St Petersburg). We had ample time to marvel at the intricate eggs and other decorative items, and to enjoy being in another restored palace. Privately owned, but the building and its contents were treated with great sensitivity.
Wow. A small museum with the best collection of Faberge Eggs in the world - 9. Don't missing if you are in St Petersburg. Try to get tickets in advance.

Staggeringly beautiful.. I was a little dubious about this visit but was glad that we went there. The work and the displays are stunning especially when you think of the time it must have taken to produce these items. It's not just Faberge eggs, it's a whole range of wonderful handicrafts that I didn't realise had been made by Faberge. No problems with photography as we were allowed to film whatever we wanted. Well worth a visit.
Not to be missed. I did not realize how much more there was to this museum. While the Faberge Eggs are by far the highlight, there are many more beautiful pieces tolerant about.

Faberge Eggs!. I always thought the glitz was over the top, but when you see the eggs in person you can appreciate the workmanship. The stories that go with the eggs are interesting as well. A highlight of our trip

The Hidden Jewel of St. Petersburg. I'm not sure why, but the Internationally-recognized guide book I studied before going to Russia did not list this Museum. Likewise, the group tour I was on did not even mention it and only 2 of the 24 people on the tour knew about it. Luckily I came across it whilst studying a map of St. Petersburg and I hot-footed down there at my earliest opportunity. What a treasure!! if you love decadence, unsurpassed craftsmanship or just plain Bling, then you can't miss this fabulous Museum. What is more, they are friendly, welcoming and you can even take pictures without stuffy officials breathing down your neck. Go after 6pm and you can wander around on your own until 8.15pm or so.

Loved it. A small but lovely museum with a lot of beautiful items produced by the famous Fabergé. If you are fed up with crowds of tourists, queing/waiting and unorganized big musea and palaces, go here! Their Museum Cafe is nice designed and had great cappucino.
Delightful. This small museum shows a private collection of beautiful works by Faberge. For those interested in Faberge works this is a "must see".

Riveria Travel Tour. Not sure why this was not featured in the Top 10 must see in St. Petersberg as we found it an excellent museum. The audio tour is well worth it and photos are allowed without flash.

Great collection!. I thought it was a great couple of hours well spent. The eggs of course are the focus, but there is plenty more to see. The palace itself is lovely and the art and artifacts are really quite interesting. The audio tour is worth the 150 rubles, but if you prefer, you can use the guide book that is free and available in English in the first room you enter.

you have to see other wise you have not been to St.Petersburg.. houses the former Malcolm Forbes collections of works by Faberge masters ,including the nine famous imperial Easter eggs that are made with the highest jewellery skills ,I called it the most expensive egg shells on earth and what a Beauty ?also they have modern Russian masters 19th-20th centuries .

A Must Do. What a great surprise! This new museum not only has Faberge Eggs, we were so amazed with all of the other items Faberge made - they sparkle and share the history of Russia all in an intimate setting. The jewelry, trinkets, and china are amazing. We were a little confused by the ticketing office. What we realized is that you don't need an actual appointment time unless you want a guided tour. We found the individual ticket + audio tour to be a perfect way to experience Faberge Museum.

Just the right size!. We managed to get into the Faberge Museum on our 3rd attempt. The first time it was closed, the second they had stopped selling tickets unless you had pre booked online. This was due to rain making it a popular destination. It does mean that there are not too many visitors at any one time.We finally made it in on our last morning arriving at about 10am, when there was no queue and not many visitors. We hired an audio guide which made it more interesting. Having seen the Faberge exhibition at the Hermitage we were surprised that a lot of the exhibits were from the time of Faberge but by other St Petersberg craftsmen. The museum is well laid out, and allows photos without flash, unfortunately when I changed my camera setting the flash came on unexpectedly and a security guard pounced, I apologised profusely and no more was said.My favourite rooms were the enamelled boxes and the eggs.

Excellent new museum. This is the only private museum in the city and the 2nd largest collection of Faberge eggs in the world. They have Faberge's original egg made for the Royal family. There are also rooms displaying silver, gold & enamel. It's a visual overload.
Fantastic!. The enamel clocks and cigarette cases to me fare exceeded the Eggs, and they were amazing! The cours and workmanship is stunning. Though a small museum it is an absolute must see.

Must see for Egg lovers. What a great collection of Faberge works including many Easter Eggs done for the royal family. Housed in a lovely palace, things are beautifully presented and a joy to behold. True history and beauty in one.

FABULOUS. Beautiful works of art
the famous eggs
A lot of sliver craftsmanship
and absolutely beautiful cigarette cases
all exposed in beutiful rooms

Extensive collection. The Faberge museum is packed with all kinds of bling-bling art work, including a collection of truly amazing Faberge eggs. It takes a lot of time if you want to understand and "dig deeper" even if for a small number of objects. For this, not to get overwhelming and tired, it is best to pay extra and take a tour gide (not an audio guide)! The tour guide will explain in an easy an entertaining manner, while the audio guide is much more extensive.The museum's interior itself is also worth seeing.

Overwhelming!. Faberge museum was the first and the last museum that I visited in St. Petersburg. Here's why: The amount of gold, art, exhibits, patterns, colours and glitz surpasses my imagination. The museum has "only" three floors, but they are surreal.You can reach the museum only on foot. There is a security check at the enterance, and they you proceed to the reception. Tickets can be paid by cash and by credit card. Someone will hand you slippers, and you should leave your belonging in a locker (left from the enterance). Toilets are also there (big, clean).Three floors of the museum are filled with all the decadent/rich/beutiful things of the world. It will take 2-3 hours for a rapid scan. This is a good introductory course for people who are planning to visit Ermitraz.Dress nicely, locals find the visit to a museum as a cultural event.There is a small shop/cafe in the museum, if you are hungry or overwhelmed by the glitz and blitz, cross the river and have a snack in cafe pyrogi (the first building left after you cross the river).

craftsmanship / Money. It is a Museum that should be on your list to see. You need to get tickets and a time before going . I scheduled ours through our ship the Silver Seas and walked in at the set time with no waiting. Great craftsmanship aided by lots of money and time . There are other items shown other than " eggs "

Yes - Faberge is fabulous. One of the highlights of our trip to St. Petersburg. Not too crowded. Lovely modern café. Super loos (not always the case).Housed in a wonderful converted Palace and the exhibits defy description. Fabulous!

Worth waiting for!. We visited this Museum as there was very little of Faberge in the Hermitage, we expected to see only the Imperial eggs, what was there was much, much more! the intricate but beautiful work was a joy to behold, ma must see if in St Petersburg.

A must see..... Oh my word, you will not be disappointed by this Museum it is filled with the most beautiful treasures of Carl Faberge. The beauty of the pieces in the museum are wonderful. You are allowed to take pictures which is great and the shop has many books and brochures as well as eggs and other things to buy, allow time for this. It was fantastic.
Faberge museum. Most exciting to see such beauty still exists and so well preserved Beautiful building and was not rushed at all

Russian indulgence at it's best/worse. Go! Really is an eye opener of the Royal Russian's love of expensive gifts/artefacts .
Not expensive entry price and so many priceless objects to look at.

Eggs are Simply Amazing. I am not even a museum lover and thoroughly loved this museum. You don't need more than 45 minutes to look at the many, many items produced by the Faberge Company - but the mechanical features of these eggs are like finely crafted Swiss watches. Mesmerizing.
It's getting there. Not a crowded collection, but if you want to see the famous eggs, many are here. It's new and they're adding more, so it's not five star yet.
Hmmmmm. It was something my spouse wanted to do so we did. It was ok however there are many other things we could have done that would have been more exciting. Zzzzzzzz......

This is how to build a museum. Unlike many sights in St. P that are tired of welcoming tourists, the Faberge Museum is still fresh and welcoming. New inside. Excellent displays and lighting. Good audio guide. Free booties required to cover shoes. Free baggage check lockers. Worth the price. Note, they do have some famous eggs but the majority of the museum is for other Faberge creations. Until recently, the museum was not open to walk-ins. Now it is. No line likely for tickets. In a very good location on a canal just off the Nevsky Prospect. As with all sights in Russia, don't trust your guidebook or a www for operating days/hours. Have your hotel call and confirm.
Boring for guys. Most guys will quickly find themselves in the two rooms with paintings. See if you can find the peasant girl who appears in two paintings. Relatively small museum. Booties required.

One of our favourites. This was amazing and so glad with travelled with Denrus as many companies did not include this in their 2 day tour. There are 9 eggs here donated by the billionaire Malcolm Forbes. The other surviving 12 are in Moscow. You are allowed to take pictures but no flash photography.

Not just Eggs!. Only 50 imperial eggs were ever made by Carl Faberge. After the 1918 revolution and massacre of the ruling family, the eggs were scattered across the world. Three are owned by Queen Elizabeth II; 10 are in Moscow; seven are lost; and the nine on display in the museum which opened in November 2013 formed part of the Forbes Collection in America until they were bought by Viktor Vekselberg, one of Russia’s richest men, for $100m in 2004. There is a lot more to the museum then just the Faberge Eggs.

Out of this World. Words cannot describe the beauty of every collection in this museum. I can't imagine that one person could have such imagination in creating the pieces that are stored there. Worth every penny.

North capital vacation . What a wonderful museum. Everything, starting from the building itself and the exhibitions are just stunning. Audio guide in Russian and English we rented for free is very helpful and informative. There are also books with detailed description of each item. Must see!

Now with photography permitted. This privately owned museum has Nine imperial Faberge eggs, including the first (my personal favourite) and the last, as well as a wide variety of other objets d'art of the period. Located in a palace, the collection is a glittering display. Well worth a visit, and during the high season, much more manageable than the Hermitage craziness

Amazing Little Museum. This private collection museum sits right on one of the canals in the heart of St. Petersburg. There were about 10 Faberge eggs but so much more as well! They have multiple Aivazovsky paintings that were truly breath taking. Worth the visit of you can spare an extra hour during your trip!!!

More Than Just Eggs. We were on a mission to see as many Faberge eggs as possible. And this was worth the walk. The museum is in a magnificent "home" that is perfectly restored. The collection is beyond beautiful. The eggs, many with their "surprises" displayed nearby, are resplendent. There is so much more to see including jewellery, icons and some works other masters.

Eggs!. The Faberge Museum is in a beautiful building and it is full of beautiful things. The eggs are the centerpiece but there are icons that are amazing and lots of silver and gold pieces. Just beautiful!

This is not a must see but great if you like eggs. We were not sure what to expect from this museum. They have around 12 eggs with very good explanations if you get the audio guide. There were not that many eggs produced for the royal family so to see this many with the explanations was very good.I would not forgo seeing some of the other amazing sites but if you have a spare hour, we were not disappointed.

Exquisite!. We did the Faberge boat ride first which introduced us to St Petersburg in the time of this great jeweller artist. When we went into the museum, we had a clear picture of Russian society in his time, his clients and the remarkable jewellery and gift business he created. The museum is small by museum standards, and is absolutely exquisite. The exhibition is inside a palace which is in pristine condition and very beautiful. There are works of art on display as well as the extensive Faberge eggs and gift pieces. It is well worth a visit to see the fine workmanship of the Faberge eggs as well as the many other perfectly designed and executed items on display. We did not have enough time to do justice to the museum and should we ever visit St Petersburg again, we will most certainly go back and give ourselves a good two hours to enjoy this wonderful display.
Delicate beauty. To see the Imperial Eggs made by the Faberge family for the Emporers and their families brought some history alive.

Stunning art and commitment to craftsmanship: Amazing. This was one of the highlights of my trip to SPB because of the heart-stoppingly beautiful items on display (not only the eggs, but also all sorts of silverware, decorative items, architectural features, and paintings) and because fewer people are allowed in at a time versus places like the Hermitage. This means that you view the gorgeous and well-described items (via the audio-tours, very reasonably priced) in relative peace and at you own pace--making it a lovely and very memorable museum experience that is 100% unique to SPB.

Amazing not to be miised. Beautiful new museum that has large collection of Faberge eggs 9 of them and lots of jewelry and exquisite hand made crafts of the house of Faberge. Truly beautiful. Easy excess especially if you arrive before 1pm. After expect lines.

A palace and an art museum at the same time.. Of course we had seen a lot of images of Faberge-eggs, and a few in reality. But seeing so many beautiful examples in one exhibition was overwhelming. And it is not just eggs that you get (for breakfast ....), there are many others items in Faberge style like tea sets, clocks, icons etc.On top of this, the museum is in a beautiful palace on the Fontanka river, with a lot of decorated ceilings etc. Highly recommended.

For lovers of jewelry!. For lovers of jewelry. The art of the court goldsmith in historical perspective with special masterpieces,the exhibition is updated ,conveniently located on the Fontanka near Nevsky prospect!

A highlight of our trip. Two hours of utter enchantment perusing this wonderful collection in a beautiful setting. Unlike The Hermitage which can be overwhelming and so packed with fellow tourists so that it is difficult to get near objects or artwork the Faberge Museum staggers entry so that you can really spend time enjoying what you're viewing. The eggs were all stunning and the artistic and historical explanations in English very welcome and interesting. The other exquisite objects of silverware and ceramics well worth spending time with too.

WOW. Where else could you see this much fabulous Faberge, the creator of more one-of-a-kind jewelry than another other jeweler in history. There have been and still are generations of the family and this is a great place to learn about them.

Exquisite Things in an Exquisite Setting. The family palace in which the large collection of Faberge Easter Eggs and other bejeweled objects of beauty are now displayed is elegant in a sort of over-the-top way. The displays are splendid, there are explanations in English and Russian, and the museum's size is, for once, manageable.

Quick tour. If you like art and design this will intrigue you for 2 hours.Just 15 mins from the hermitage, along the canal.Staff taking tickets was very busy and rude sadly.The eggs could be open too, and have magnifying glass to show details.Art and silverware are very nice too.

Faberge Eggstravaganza . The Faberge Museum is home to the second largest collection of Faberge Eggs in the world. Whilst the eggs are truly a testament to the jeweller's art, there is also an amazing collection of fine silverware and ceramics that were created for imperial clientele.

Luxury museum on Fontanka River in St.Petersburg. Here, on the embankment of Fontanka is located this privately owned museum, that is, Faberge Museum. It is placed in one of the most beautiful palaces in St.Petersburg, in the Shuvalov Palace. The Shuvalov Family was one noble Russian family, whose distinction began during the reign of Empress Elizabeth in the forties and fifties of 18th century. The Museum is really of high class style, containing the big collection of works of decorative applied and fine arts, as silver and gold items, paintings, porcelain,bronze, but above all in its beauty is the group of nine Imperial Easter eggs. They were created by the great Russian jeweler Carl Faberge to the order of Alexander III and Nicolas II.We just enjoyed in looking at these chef d'oeuvres of finest jeweled art, the eggs like Renaissance, Rosebud, Coronation and others.Just fascinating !

Well worth a visit. I had been to SPb 5 times before but this was a museum I had not visited - the highlight is a collection of a dozen or more Faberge Eggs which are fabulous to see - but in addition the palace is interesting and it has a range of other items of Russian craftsmanship - including some beautiful gold- and silver-ware

Must see visit. Stunning exhibition, a must see. We booked our tickets on line in advance for an English speaking tour, you enter the museum via a separate door and avoid the queues. The guides' English was perfect and she was very knowledgeable. Whilst you can't linger for too long, you can take photographs "of the non flashy kind". The museum has an excellent cafe, great for a spot of people watching

Faberge museum visit . The museum is located in a related building which belonged to a high class family .It was founded by Viktor Vekselberg, a rich Russian that wants to bring back lost Russian treasures .The museum us opened late so my suggestion is to go early or late .Website for ticketing not always working/note!The tour is by a guide and there is no English all the time, so check schedules constantly .The Favberge eggs are a must see!!!Don't miss!!

A lovely collection. This museum has a great collection of eggs and other pieces made by the expert craftspeople of imperial St Petersburg and Moscow. There are of course some beautiful eggs, but I would have liked to have seen more.Get an audioguide or guided tour, as the exhibits themselves do not have descriptions attached. I learned a lot about the history of the companies, the building, and the imperial families from the audioguide. Well worth a visit.

A beautiful collection of Faberge. Unlike the Hermitage, this museum is much more tightly controlled in terms of the number of people allowed in at once. Thus is is much easier to get close to the exhibits. Very interesting.

Great collection. Don't expect to see only eggs, this is far more than this.It is a travel through Russian history with a beautiful collection.It is nevertheless quite busy.The museum also offer temporary exhibition.

Awesome Eggs!. If you're a fan of beautiful and rare faberge eggs, this museum is a must visit. From historical events to modern day, these intricate pieces of art mark important chapters in world history. A lovely way to spend a couple of hours.
Wonderful Collection of Craftmanship. Worthy of a visit for anyone who likes silverware and gilded worksFaberge museum is a masterpiece like the items produced by the Master

Stunning collection. A fascinating collection and the highlight has to be the room housing beautiful Faberge eggs! Don't leave it until the last minute to visit this museum, particularly if you want a guided tour because they only sell a certain allocation of tickets for each hour of the day. We managed to squeeze in on an un-guided tour, but there are audio guides you can hire. I was pleasantly surprised that you are allowed to take photographs.

Stunning Eggs!. Enjoyed an evening visit to this very interesting museum. Of course, the Faberge Eggs are the centerpiece of the museum but there are many other beautiful imperial items to enjoy. The audio narration gives a lot of detail about the eggs and there is a nice gift shop where I purchased an egg pendant to bring home. Leave 1 1/2 to 2 hours to experience the museum.

Amazing. The best assortment of Faberge items under one roof, with the odd Renoir on the wall, perfect if you like artistic money no object jewellery and personal items encrusted with as many diamonds as possible.

Beautiful . This is a great place to go on a rainy day. It only takes about an hour to go around and the main attraction is the room with 8 of the Faberge eggs in. There are many more rooms filled with other luxurious items. Unless you understand Russian you can't get an audio guide, but there is a book in English to guide you through everything. It costs about £4.50 to go in and you can buy tickets online beforehand.

Faberge Museum. Fantastic smaller venue! A privately owned and operated museum featuring a number of Imperial Eggs from the renowned Faberge jewelry purchased from the late Malcolm Forbes estate as well as a number of other pieces and religious icons. Amazingly the museum allows photography who so often seems restricted (think the entire Peterhof and the amber room at Catherine Palace).

Not another museum. An outstanding display of exquisite objects d'art, with over 4,000 pieces including nine imperial Faberge eggs. The Shuvalov Palace itself is beautifully decorated and well maintained. Organised tours are available or you can hire headset or just wander around. Cameras are allowed. Centrally located. A real must see.

Fabulous, favorite museum in St Petersburg. This museum is housed in a Palace on the Fontanka river in St Petersburg. It was my favorite museum in St Petersburg. The Palace has been beautifully restored and the rooms are spectacular. There is one gallery dedicated to the Faberge Eggs, with each displayed in their own case. (If you have been to the Kremlin you will have seen them tucked into overstuffed cases where you have to spot them for yourself) The other galleries have incredible displays of everything else Faberge produced as well as fine objects produced by his (their ?) contemporaries. You have to don cloth booties to tour the museum which showed me how serious they are about protecting the beautiful restored Palace. The audio guide is well worth it but in addition there are guide books in each room that describe each item in the display cabinets. I felt they could have given more anecdotal information on the eggs, but there were several private english tours roaming the gallery so I just listened in. They also have a lovely little cafe with light snacks tea and coffee etc.

Exquisite !!. Amazing museum!!The perfection and superb craftsmanship of all of Faberge's pieces places these creations in a class by themselves...... Intricate using the finest and most precious stones.....So beautiful.. that one can only marvel at their beauty...The museum itself is also architecturally beautiful !!A must see!!!!

Faberge Lovers Dream. My favorite museum in St Petersburg. It's only been open for a few years and is housed in a renovated palace. Everything is beautifully lit and displayed unlike the Hermitage which can be very dark. The highlight is of course their fabulous collection of eggs which includes the very first and last eggs made. We came with a guide so not sure how individual ticketing works, but the entries are timed and they limit the number of visitors each day. A big plus because you will actually be able to see and enjoy all the displays. So many amazing things to see you can easily spend several hours although the guide does keep you moving through each room pretty quickly. Ours was getting quite disturbed that there were a few people just roaming from room to room. He said they are usually quite strict about the order you go through the rooms and that you stay with your own group. So.... Be prepared to follow some rules but you will appreciate the orderliness and lack of big crowds. We also enjoyed the gift shop. It's small but has a nice variety of souvenirs and wide range of prices. There's a very guide book for just 200 rubles.

Very Pleasant Visit. To be fair you are probably only going to visit the museum if you have some interest in Faberge/ art jewellery. If you have no interest then you won't enjoy it. We loved it, purely as we like things of this type. The collection is vast and covers a huge range of their work. The eggs are worth seeing and it's not expensive. They also have a very pleasant cafe and art collection. Well worth the entry fee!

Breathtaking. A small yet wonderful museum in the centre of St Petersburg - this is a private museum and so the length of your visit is timed - we were with an organised tour - and our guide was very informative without bombarding us with too much information. The exhibits are outstanding - and although the Imperial eggs are the stars of the museum there are so many other beautiful objects that the time is just not long enough to see everything. This is the first year that interior photography has been allowed. There is a small shop where you can buy books and souvenirs ( they only take roubles) and staff are friendly yet discreet. Well worth a visit.

See 9 eggs. The highlight here is obvious the 9 Faberge Eggs. There are other Faberge items here, filling another half a dozen or so rooms. There's a limited number of entries in each time slot, so I assume you may be denied entry, but we had no problem in mid-afternoon.
Wonderful........ To see all the beautiful items that take your imagination back in time. The museum is not too large and we took our time in our two hour window.
A lovely experience!. Not only was the exhibit breathtakingly beautiful but the staff was very friendly and helpful.I would definately recommend a visit there when in Saint Petersburg!
Amazing but grossly overpriced for the Size.. Frankly I was hoping to see many more varieties of Faberge eggs and much more jewelry and art collection. The ticket price is way too high for its size.

If you love Faberge then this is a must. I love Faberge his jewelled eggs are just breathtaking and this museum is in a restored palace that has had a lot of time an effort lavished on it to make it really magical. Th collection is superb

Great afternoon . Limited admission private museum that has numerous Faberge eggs but also hundreds of other items on display. Beyond the glitz it's a window into the families that once ruled Russia. History and beauty.

Beautiful building and wonderful objects of art. I found this museum on the TripAdvisor website. We visited the museum early evening on the day of our arrival in St Petersburg and it was well worth the visit. We didn't have a guide but did pay for the audio guide, the entry fee and audio guide are very reasonably priced. The collection is housed in a beautiful building which has been refurbished to a very high standard. You will not be disappointed if you want to see Faberge Easter eggs, but there's so much more to see, exquisite enamel objects by Faberge and other craftsmen. A real highlight of our first visit to St Petersburg and indeed to Russia - a must see!

Get the audio guide . One is allowed to visit and take photos at your own leisure without joining the Russian tours. We did so at 10:00 in the morning, but without a bit more background (i.e. an audio guide) the museum is not great. Cost is RUB450 per adult.

well worth the visit after a long full day. The eggs are very special but lots of other fine works of Faberge and other craftsman. The building that houses the exhibit is beautiful too. They have an english audioguide that was good but look for a book in most of the rooms that have an english guide book with better explanations and very detailed descriptions. It helped alot. Allow about 1 1/2 hr to see it or maybe a little more time. We were very glad we went.

A-ma-zing. By chance I watched a documentary on the Faberge family on the plane ride to Russia which documented their history as jewelers to the czars. I have seen a few Faberge eggs in DC at the Hillwood museum, but was truly blown away by the 9 eggs on display here. Most tourists go in quickly, look at the egg and then spend more time taking photos. I actually spent quite a bit of time there just looking at each egg, and experiencing it before returning to take photos. Love this museum!!!
Great. Excellent collection in a grand palace. The only thing I would recommend is - take a guide or at least an audio guide as most of the items have no info on display.
A nice small museum with those great eggs. This is a nice compact museum whose highlight are the Faberge eggs. It also has some nice silver and other items that make for a pleasant visit.

Private tour. What a unique place. It doesn't take long to go through this gem of s museum. Each piece was explained in detail by our guide. It is a relatively new museum and well worth the visit. It takes about an hour to see all the eggs on display.

A small museum with outstanding contents. The Faberge eggs that were made for the relatives of the Tsar's are gorgeous. The building itself is beautiful. The mecum also has sample of dishes, small boxes, jewelry - all designed by Faberge. There are only a few other Faberge eggs in private collections and museums around the world so this is the place to see them.

EXQUISITE EGGS. This museum houses the world's most complete collection of Fabergé eggs, all immaculately crafted by jeweller to the tsars, Carl Fabergé. Nine priceless, imperial Fabergé eggs of the fifty made are displayed with due reverence, the precious stones that encrust them lit so that they sparkle brilliantly. Simply breathtaking. The building itself is a site of grandeur and compliments the display. When you have feasted your eyes on the Fabergé eggs, move on to the other treasures on display, all tastefully mounted and worthy of independent exhibition. Wonderful knowledgeable guide enthralled with details of items exhibited.Admittance is controlled so that you are not surrounded by hordes of people. Cameras are allowed and the exhibition is a photographer's dream.

More than jeweled eggs. Went here and had the guided tour. The tour is conducted in Russian but you can get audio tours in other languages. I understand Russian so the regular tour was fine. Very informative and really great examples of jeweled eggs and enamel pieces, icons, silver and more. Located along the Fontanka River just off Nevsky Prospekt. Get tickets online ahead of time.

Great exhibition. Fine display of Fabergé eggs and other Russian art, you should reserve enough time to enjoy this beautiful exhibition (one hour is not nearly enough). The audio guide is easy to use and is very thorough. The building itself is beautiful as well.
Faberge Museum. This was much more spectacular then I could have imagined. The size and grandeur of the rooms is a real credit to those who put it back together after being damaged so badly.

amazing collection, but everything else.... We went there late and we had to wait there for a long time, and only reason why we finally got in us that we booked it long time ago. The eggs and everything else was amazing, but we could not stay and see thing for over an minute beacuse the tour. We also were not alloud to take pictures. The security was wachibg us all the time and if we get a little closer to the glass or something else they emmideatly comed to warn us. Reconmend only for the collection.

Fab - erge. Bit expensive for Russia but worth it. There are a few rooms with good displays and the building itself is nice but the star of the show is the room given over to the faberge eggs which are simply exquisite. It's worth getting the audio guide to see how much craftsmanship went into creating them.

Surprising, and breathtaking, even if you are not into jewelry. This new museum, set in a beautifully restored private mansion, has a wonderful collection of objects from Karl Faberge's firm. The name is French, but he was born in St. Petersburg, and brought his father's jewelry firm up to world class levels, providing the Romanovs and their associates incredibly detailed and richly decorated eggs, along with other objects. The imperial egg collection alone is worth the visit, but there are so many other beautiful objects as well - a snail, a peasant worked in brightly colored stones. Very well displayed. Ticket office opens at 9:30, but the museum not until 10:00. Get the audio guide, even if you only use it to hear about the eggs.
Mind Blowing. The most exquisite exhibits in the most beautiful palace. Laid out perfectly with excellent explanation. An absolute delight.

Home of Romanov Faberge Eggs. Used the audio guide to tour the Faberge Museum. For us, the eggs were the highlight of the tour. Hearing about each egg's story was well worth the price of the audio guide!

A must if in St Petersburg. Can now be visited by individuals all day up to closing time at 2045.We went at 1800 and it was relatively quiet.No groups at this time.Spent 1.5hrs here to see eggs and much much more.No photo signs but most visitors seemed to ignore this.

Not to be missed. This is a 'must' on any visit to St Petersburg. You can get right up close to the exhibits and even touch the huge urns (but best bit to!!). Check opening times as they do change at different times of the year.

Wow!. This is a must see museum, not big but packed with the most exquisite enamel and silver objects. Of course the eggs are amazing. They renovated the old palace where in the USSR was the Friendship House. The rooms themselves are beautiful. They have a nice shop as well.
Stunning collection of exquisite art. This is a must see, amazing collection of eggs, jewellery, enamel ware, silverware. Breathtaking. Exquisite!

An opportunity to see "those" eggs up close and personal!. I was recommended this new museum by a business associate as somewhere you really ought to go if you have a couple of hours to spare. Located 200 metres along the Fontanka Embankment off Nevskiy Prospect in the restored Shuvalov Palace, it must be convenient for most visitors.This is a small, private museum, fresh and new (2013), with modern presentation and lighting. The paintings are particularly well lit, and they appear to glow as though back-lit.There are many works to be seen, about 4000, which demonstrate the amazing abilities of the Faberge house, though the eggs are the centrepiece for obvious reasons.Make sure you at least take the audio tour, or even the guided tour - there are no explanatory notes on the exhibits. The prices are very reasonable - the guided tour was about £10.Be sure to take the time to look at the rooms themselves, not just the bling.There is the obligatory gift shop at the exit, stocked with all things Faberge.
Very impressive!. A small but nice museum, detailing about Fabergé. Learned a lot, most interesting fact that he made more than eggs alone :).

Beautiful Collection. We arrived after 6pm as from 10-6pm it is excursions only, and the museum does not open on Fridays. There are plenty of museums in St Petersburg but the Faberge museum is definitely worth a visit. You are requested to go the cloakroom to put on foot socks for your shoes before starting the tour.There is so much more to see than just the Faberge eggs which are not only intricate and beautiful. The various rooms also house art work and silver collections. Its amazing how so many of the pieces are just housed behind glass so you can actually get right up close

Excellent museum. I enjoyed my time here. The museum is a perfect size. Not too big and not too small. There are 7/8 rooms and you can comfortably cover everything in an hour although the official tour is 2 hours. Only 1 tour in English at 4pm so I decided to use the English audio guide and have a go myself. I was glad I did as I think I might have been bored with a 2 hour tour. The audio guide needs a cash or cloakroom receipt as deposit but allows you to get a description of the room you are in and it's particular design features and also a description of the content of some of the display cases. You therefore choose the ones you are interested in and only need to listen to those. All of the pieces (particularly the world famous eggs) on display were exquisite, intricate and beautifully handcrafted pieces. Well worth a visit.

A lot more than "just" eggs. The famous Faberge eggs are a must see when visiting St. Petersburg, but the museum has so much more than "just" the eggs. All kinds of fancy art is here, around 4000 pieces in total. However, as St. Petersburg is filled with all kinds of amazing things, it still falls short of places like the Hermitage Museum. I do anyway recommend going to the museum, and it's free if you have the Petersburg Card.
Faberge Museum. This museum was pretty amazing. It not only had the eggs but it had everything he has ever made. It was five rooms of incredible Faberge items.

Beautiful. So much more to Faberge than his amazing eggs. This museum has one room of the royal eggs, and several rooms of other amazing items including snuff boxes, lamps, and jewelry. Be sure to purchase the audio tour to insure you get the story behind all the items.

City Tour. This tour was not offered by the Cuise Ship. Small museum but inside you get to see 11 Faberge eggs and there secrets inside. Beautiful. As well there is more to see than just the Fab. Eggs.

Beautiful museum. Very nice museum. I rented the audio guide, which added to my enjoyment of the museum. The palace is quite stunning. I loved the Faberge eggs, which were displayed beautifully. I also loved the collection of icons. Very worthwhile visit.

More eggs than you can afford.. Located in a beautiful palace, this collection of masterpieces is amazing. One cannot help but admire the perfection in the details. No matter how tiny they are. You will never be satisfied with a Kinder Egg again.

Fun tour! Loved the history of Faberge. Very interesting tour including the Faberge eggs, which are the main attraction, but also many other things produced by Faberge. Interesting history! Such a must see. Does not take long, about an hour, but very interesting. Largest collection of Faberge eggs in the world. If you also go to Moscow, you can see quite a few in the Kremlin Museum also.

A real gem to visit. I had read mixed reviews about this museum, but I loved it. True, there are only a selection of Faberge eggs on display but they are magnificent, but there are lots of rooms containing other displays linked to the Faberges and these are excellent. Moreover, the building itself and the paintings therein are worth seeing as well. I had also read conflicting information about how to get in - some sites said you could only enter as part of a guided tour before 18.00. This was not the case. We arrived at 13.45 on a Saturday afternoon; there were no queues and we simply walked in, bought an audio guide along with our ticket, and spent two hours inside. I had read that guided tours were one hour long and did see some people bring whisked through the exhibitions by a guide at great speed. Doing it at your own speed is much nicer. Please note, the museum is closed on Fridays.

Fantastic. Here's some tips. We visited as a couple.You can book online, and collect tickets at the desk, or buy on the day.You can hire audio guides, have a guided tour, or just wander around. A returnable deposit is required for each audio guide.You're required to wear overshoes over your shoes, and to check your bag in the lockers in the cloakroom.Photos are allowed, but not with flash.There is a very good cafe, as well as a gift shop. There are guidebooks in English and Russian, however these give relatively little information.The building is exquisite, and the display and artefacts are absolutely amazing.Allow between 1 and 3 hours for your visit - depending on your level of interest.A real gem.
A-MAZ-ING!. Don't miss this - it's incredible. Who knew that Faberge made knitting pins? And to see these Easter eggs, and read the stories behind them - this is an amazing museum. Don't miss it.
Lots of bling!. Beautiful building with such ornate works of art from eggs to silver to oil paintings loved it. Get a QR reader on your phone for a free audio guide

Breathtaking. My 21 year old daughter and I visited the Faberge museum last week and it is simply breathtaking! Not only is the collection stunning and expansive, including not only the signature eggs, but also art, ceramics and silver, but the curation is exceptional.The museum is light, airy, well run and hugely informative. I particularly liked the way the displays were presented....for me the highlight of my St Petersburg trip. I highly recommend a visit! Great value for money.

All is in the Egg. Detail, imagination, beauty, minerals of all sorts, attention to others, all these pieces of jewellry are made to express your love to someone, showing that you thoughts with details. This goes far beyond a letter or flowers, as it is eternal, so precious stones, of ideas, colors, surprises,... These pieces are surely the flag of Russian artistic talents.

Beautifull. Amazing history, definitely worth visiting
We took the boat after and it was amazing, I recommend both.
The museum is full of history and not expensive

Cool Museum. If you have time, this is a cool museum to visit. It's a private museum so the ticket was a little expensive but we had 8 days in St. Petersburg. It's cool to see the original Faberge eggs made for royalty. You won't see it anywhere else so if this is something that interests you, take the time to visit this museum.
Most beautiful stuff I've ever seen. They had Frida Kahlo exhibition going on atm (not anymore) which is cool. But the permanent collection of Faberge's pieces of art is amazing! Worth the money!

Exquisite Faberge Eggs. We were fortunate enough to see the exquisite Faberge eggs in this museum. Apparently an Oligarch bought these eggs back from the Forbes family and restored them to Russia. The craftsmanship is awesome and the detailing and mechanisms are truly impressive. The sad bit was that after being the favoirite of the Csars family, the revolution forced Faberge and his family to flee to Paris where he died in Penury. Also, an American company patented the name so any Faberge items you buy now, are pale imitations of the real thing.

Interesting and educative visit, YES you can take photos too!!. Everyone knows the famous Faberge eggs! This is why we decided to visit this museum. We booked the English tour (only one available per day, for groups of 10 people max). Unfortunately, one of the members of the staff informed us that we were not allowed to take photos during our tour, so we left our cameras at the cloakroom with the rest of our things. To our great disappointment, when the tour began, our lovely guide Eugenia, let us know that we WERE allowed to take pictures as long as we didn't use any flashes. So many amazing eggs -and not only-, and we didn't photograph anything...luckily we bought a guide of the museum which included all the exhibits, for a reasonable price, and we have something to remember the museum by. In general, it is a museum well-worth visiting, since it combines great exhibits and information about the history of the creator, that visitors would appreciate. Do not miss it!

If you fancy Faberge eggs, this is the place to visit. What can I say. If you find Faberge eggs fascinating and beautiful, then this museum should be on your list to visit. Beautiful artistry in each egg.

Fabulous Faberge. The Museum is housed in a renovated Palace and has not been open all that long. The Palace is beautiful and all the exhibits were beautifully show. Lots of amazing Faberge eggs, jewels etc. It is a large museum with lots to see, even if you are not interested in jewellery.

Truly Amazing !. This museum has not been open for long but it is well worth the visit when you consider all the history relating to these eggs. The workmanship is magnificent and the guides are extremely knowledgable. To see these priceless items close up was worth every penny, especially when you consider in London and Paris that similar would be roped off and you would be lucky to get within 20 feet ! The palaces and museums in St Petersburg are fantastic but this is a must see in my view.

A beautiful collection of Faberge house in the exquisitely restored Schouvalof Palace. You are obliged to join a guided group, which makes it slow, but the tour comprises many exquisite pieces of Faberge, including 5 Imperial eggs and some enchanting small objects. The Schouvalof Palace in which it is housed has been beautifully restored and makes a perfect setting for the collection.

Exquisite Things. Small newer museum with tit security, and for good reason. Jaw dropping priceless exquisite things. A range of Faberge eggs as well as other priceless Russian finery. If you like exquisite jewellery don't miss this!
Beautiful but no eggs.. Had hoped to see some of Faberge's amazing eggs but was disappointed. However the rest of the collection was stunning.

Thank you for the Frida Kahlo exhibition. The museum is situated at the end of the main street Nevsky. I visited the Faberge Museum mainly because of the Frida Kahlo exhibition. It warmed my heart to see many locals filling the exhibition. Cloakroom service was free, I rented the audioguide in English, bought the ticket and everything cost less than 9 euros. I spent one hour and it was a life-changing experience. Would have loved to see the standard exhibition, but didn't have the time.

Fabulous Faberge. We spent an hour marvelling at the beautiful objects on display. The highlight was the collection of Faberge Eggs but there was so much more to see. A "must see" when in St Petersburg.

Torturege Museum. If antique eggs tickle your fancy and you have high levels of patience this is your place to be! Pre booked online tickets advisable. Avoid guided tour if you have ADD tendencies. Probably one of the safest places in St. Petersburg, very well guarded.
the right choice. very nice museum, plenty of elegant and interesting exhibits, if you do not wish to be out, this is the right choice

Special place. I've waited a long time to see this work , I adore it. Great price , lots and lots to see . I wasn't disappointed - it was amazing. Book online to save queuing , book an audio machine too though if you want to here the tour in your own language (they had run out for us )

5*****+ experience. I can't even describe how blown away I was...And still am when I think of this beautiful museum and all the exponents. It truly is one of the best museums to visit in Russia. Beautiful interiors match perfectly with exponents - the highest esthetical experience of the whole trip! I took lot of photos and I decided very well to go there after 6pm when you're not even limited with the guided tour (during which you're not spending more than one hour in the museum and you're not allowed to go back and see it on your own) but you also have the whole museum for yourself- at least after 7pm- still, the museum is opened until 8:45pm so you can have at least 2 hours and 45 minutes to enjoy it on your own. You can find all the informations in free visitors guide or you can have an audio guide- both are OK but for me. I wish I came back one more time!

Historical Bling at it artistic best. Closed during the season on Fridays. There are only a few English language tours in a day and you have to join a tour (though there are audio guides) during normal hours so choose carefully. After 6pm there is no such restriction and that was when we went and had unrestricted reign.What can you say about such fantastic artistry and workmanship. Its totally awe inspiring even if you do not like the style. Worth a visit - entry about £4.50.

Limited, improved with co-existant art exhibition. Really limited Faberge collection, I was quite surprised, as everyone in Moscow had raised expectations. Great English written guide, but frankly found the museum with teenagers (even one interested in jewellery) pretty tedious. Inexpensive to get in though

Fantastic - a must see. This is a beautiful building filled with even more beautiful things. Unfortunately you have to have a guide and it only lasts an hour. Wish it had been longer. Only one English tour a day. Book online a week before on the website and it is cheap. The tickets go fast but you can book on the Internet and then you avoid the queues outside. Cafe looks lovely too

Faberge Museum St Petersburg. Wow! You can't photograph anything (great quality book with images available at the store when you exit) but just to see them was a marvellous experience. Words cannot do the eggs justice. This is a MUST SEE when in St Petersburg

Fabulous opulence at its finest. I was in awe of this beautiful collection of objects, too fabulous to describe. You must visit this museum. Be aware that the tours are timed so book ahead. There are English tours and our guide threw a whole new light on this collection. Well worth a visit at about £5 a ticket. Tours last almost 1.5 hours. It is situated just off the major road Nevsky Prospect, alongside the canal. Get off the hop on bus at stop 9 or 10.

Only good if you like this sort of thing.. Well, my wife, daughters and I went to visit, and 2 of us liked it, but 2 of us got bored. There's a bit of a palaver to start, meaning you have to adorn shoe protectors, and the exhibition itself isn't particularly big. However, you cannot fail to be impressed by the Faberge Eggs, which are unique. Other than that, I found it tedious. In the Souvenir Shop, you'll be pleasantly surprised to find that everything is very reasonably priced indeed.
Marvelous place. Really nice place, atmospheric place, luxurious and magnificent. There is a collection of Faberge eggs, silver and enamel items.

Good tour. We did a 1 hour tour of this place. I think that you can only visit on a tour during the day.The tour guide was great. She spoke good english with a posh accent which was easy to understand. She was very knowledgeable and passionate about Faberge.

Fantastic museum of the Faberge house of art.. Be advised to book in advance, especially if you'd like the English speaking guided tour. We got lucky & got the remaining 2 spaces. Amazing works of art which we looked at with the guide. You can't go to St. Petersburg without going!

Nice cozy place, but its kinda small. We did a guided tour for both Faberzhe eggs and Frida Kahlo exhibition. Both were great, although I was left wanting more. Faberzhe one is like 10 rooms, yet the Easter Eggs are all in one room. Rest are kinda your typical 18s century plates etcFrida was awesome- dont think you get a chance to see her works much, heard Mexico aint keen for them to travel (or maybe just a marketing spin?).
Very nice. The little crafted eggs and jewelry showcase a perfect portray of Zarist Russia and its elegance and wealth.

Wonderful tour. The website is quite well done but it is a little confusing about getting tours in English. I think the way it works is that you have to get them a week or less in advance. The English tours are only once a day at 4:00. It's well worth going on the tour (it may be required?). It is only one hour. The Easter eggs are the highlight, of course, but there are nice displays of silver and enamel. The old mansion is a beautiful setting and the cafe downstairs is quite nice for a coffee, dessert or quick bite to eat.

Eggs eggs eggs. This is what a lot of tourists have come to see and the museum doesn't disappoint with 13 eggs and other jewels to see. Exhibits are a bit unexciting and would have liked more of a story but a must see if visiting the city...... There is an art exhibit in the other half of the museum,

Go and see the Faberge Eggs- easier to access than the Kremlin. You must go to Russia and see the world famous Faberge eggs. Unfortunately , there are very few of those eggs around. The biggest collection is on Moscow's amourery in the Kremlin which is almost next to impossible to obtain admission. The best alternative is to visit this museum which has 9 of these eggs. The Kremlin has 10. You can either book online or visit the museum. The day tours requires a guided Russian tour that you must take. You can follow the tour but listen to an audio guide or just snap pictures . The tour is about 45 minutes long and is very interesting. Besides the Faberge eggs, you also see their gold and silver rooms as well as Russian religious artifacts. It is open all day and worth your time. Admission is 450 Roubles .

Not to be missed. We visited to see the excellent Frida Kahlo exhibit and might have missed it otherwise, but that would have been a big mistake. Beautifully restored palace houses the amazing collection of Faberge artifacts including presents given by the last two emperors to their families. Very insightful and interesting guides; the main collection must be viewed as part of a group, which is well worth it. A great contribution to Russian national culture but Mr. Vekselberg and his foundation.

Amazing Collection. In addition to housing an astonishing number of Imperial Easter Eggs, the museum has hundreds of other items made by Faberge. Furthermore, the palace itself is beautiful - a perfect location for such intricate and beautiful objects.

Definately find time to visit. It's worth it!!!!!. It's really one of the best museums i've been to in past years. Everything around is so beautiful and inspiring. If you come with the group n the guide, probably u'll get more useful information.

Small but beautiful museum. We have been lucky because in addition to the regular exhibition, which is very interesting, there was a special Frida Kahlo exhibition. The museum is quite small but stunning. Each room is unique, what makes of the visit a great experience to enjoy the architectural beauties that St Petersburg has to offer.

Exquisite Easter Eggs. Visited 17/03/16. Adult cost Rubles 450.00. Reserved tickets in advance by e-mail for an English guided tour. The English tours are marked "EN" in red letters on various days through out the week. We didn't have to queue at all. Take photos as you go around as you are not allowed to go back afterwards. Coats have to go in the cloakroom and you are required to wear protective footwear over your shoes, so ladies don't wear high heals. There is another exhibition running until the 30th April 16 of Frida Kahlos work but this is another cost. The staff were very friendly and helpful. You really have to visit this place as a "must do" you will not be disappointed.
Cultural artifacts of Russia. If you like decorative artwork and to know more about the artifacts of Russian culture, this place is highly recommended.
Unforgettable place. Huge collection of masterpieces produced by Faberge manufactory, including world-famous easter eggs from Russian emperor collection. It's absolutely must see in S-Pit.

Unique Museum. Toured while on a Viking Star cruise. Beautiful museum worth a visit. The collection rivals the Louvre - it is private and very interesting. They have limited hours and seemed to control how many were in the museum so plan ahead.
Carolyn. A must see! If you don't you will regret it! The building itself is fabulous and the eggs are "jawdropping!!!! Make time to see !!!!

Shiny eggy things. Wanted to see the Faberge Eggs. This museum is easy to find along one of the embankments. Had to wear disposable slippers over my shoes once I checked in my coat. Long queue due to an art exhibition also taking place. I went after 6pm so I could take myself around without a guide... The eggs are pretty; as are all the other gold and silver pieces, as well as the rooms.

A must see destination.. This is a double whammy as you not only get to see the Faberge but the beautiful palace too. Apart from the usually mind blowing Faberge boxes and trinkets there are rooms of icons and tableware, tea services etc. All enamelled by the house of Faberge showing what a good commercial acumen Faberge had. We went on a Friday so you are free to wander round. Any other day you have to join a Russian tour group. The English groups only appeared to be once a day at 4.30pm so it is much better to wander yourself. Going in the winter meant no queues for tickets or cloakroom and you were the only person looking at each display case. Wonderful. It is open quite late each day and the later you go, the better. Allow 2 hours to go around.

Not To Be Missed By Faberge Lovers. This museum is on the Hop On Hop Off bus route but can still be hard to find a sit is in the back street along a canal. 9 Faberge eggs are housed here as well as many other marvellous items by this outstanding jewellery company. The museum is house in a stunning building.

Amazing exhibits but very baby unfriendly!. We loved the exhibits in the museum but out visit was made very difficult because we weren't allowed to take in either our pram or the baby rucksack. That meant we had to carry out wriggly 10 month old the whole time. Also, you weren't allowed to leave the tour (which was all in Russian and so nothing more than a means to see what we wanted for us) which meant we felt like we were disturbing others, constantly having to go to the other side of rooms to try and keep the little one quiet. The cafe had no baby seat and there didn't seem to be a baby change. So I'd definitely say you should visit, but if you're in st Petersburg with a baby I would take it in turns to visit rather than taking the baby with you!
Incredibly beautiful works of art. Jewellery is not normally in my interest range but this museum is really worth seeing. No wonder the Fabergé eggs are world famous.
Stunning end to our St Petersburg visit. You must go. We had to have a tour in Russian Sven rather than just wander round therefore a bit more expensive but the display were well worth a visit.

Mind-blowing. There aren't enough superlatives for this place. The building is stupendous. The jewels are jaw-dropping. The exquisite eggs are mind blowing. Visit after 6pm to wander by yourself (or on Fridays).The collection of eggs is only rivalled by the Armoury in the Kremlin in Moscow.

Wow, no wonder they had a revolution!. The eggs and other lavish objets d'art are astonishing! Really beautiful palace with a spectacular collection. Visited in the evening, open late some nights, so it was quiet (winter helped too). Both interesting and well run museum. Very helpful staff too.
Impressive. Faberge was amazing. The jewels, gold , etc., alone is worth the trip. I highly recommend it. You will not be disappointed.

Very interesting . There was a room of about 10 cabinets with eggs that we're all very beautiful. Also a room of other Faberge items, as well as rooms of paintings and other items. Was very glad to see it. Would recommend booking in peak times- we weren't there in a busy time, yet the queue took a while to process and only have a limited number of tickets available each day.

Great museum, wheelchair frendly. First I would like to say that this private museum is a brilliant cooperation between private business and the state. Its totally renewed and is in a wonderful condition. The exposition itself is very rich and demonstrates the power of Russian jewel industry of the period. Fabergé museums is not just about the famous eggs but also about all the production they've made. The interiors are very impressive! The museum is wheelchair friendly, there is an elevator, the personnel is very friendly and eager to help!
Beautiful. A breathtaking collection of art. Gold and silver items as well as painting. And the building itself is a work of art.

Worth it!. Fantastic place. Even if you do not really care about those famous eggs, do not miss this place because they have other stuff to see. Plus, the interiors are great, too.You are going to be impressed. I happened to be there when they were having an exhibition of Frida Kahlo's works. What a nice surprise!

elegant yet approachable. The Faberge museum manages to be impressive without being overwhelming. The interior is decorated beautifully and the items on display are really fascinating. My husband was quite skeptical before we went in, muttering about "overpriced eggs," but even he was won over in the end. The craftsmanship that has gone into these items is really amazing. We went in the late evening to avoid having to go on a guided tour and pretty much had the place to ourselves.
Interesting but not mind blowing.. We visited the Faberge Museum as part of a 2 day St. Petersburg tour. It was worth a visit after having travelled so far but not the highlight of the visit.

Communist style service. Place is great, collection ok but the service is terrible. One cash register, unfriendly and useless staff, had to wait due to long queue to be told that we had to wait an hour for open tours and anyway the organised tour was only in Russian...

Beautiful Minature Masterpieces . A tour that is booked in a language of your choice, which is brilliant, as Russian tourists are not always afforded foreign translations in their palaces and such like.You are then required to deposit bags and put on your protective footwear.The guides are extremely well informed and the tour goes at the right pace. You are afforded plenty of time to ask questions, but you are not allowed to browse outside of your groups.There has been a lot of thought put into this place and the amount of items brought together for this museum makes it well worth a visit. It is not as big as a lot of the other tourist attractions, but it is well worth a look.

Well worth the visit!. We were individual visitors, could only enter after 18h, and had to have a hefty sum of 4000 Rubels for the two audioguide deposits in cash. The staff were friendly, and the exhibition is fantastic, beautiful. Well worth the effort, and the audioguide!

Incredible restoration of Shuvalov Palace. What an incredibly beautiful palace. I went for the first time yesterday for the Frida Kahlo exhibit. No expense was spared to bring this palace back to life. If anything, it may be too much! Gorgeous stairway and dome. Amazing that 40 years after my first visit to this city, I still find beautiful places that I've never seen.

History of Russia is there. Enjoy Luxury and feel Russian history, please visit a web, there you can find 2 tours in English per day- it is marked with red letters! you can take an audio guide ( deposit is in rubles and will be returned at the end of the tour)Possible to take PICTURES without flash

Stunning!!. You have to visit this museum without question. The history of faberge and seeing the beautiful pieces (not just the eggs which everyone knows about) is so interesting and the works of art are simply breathtaking! We were fortunate to have one of the museum guides take us round which I would thoroughly recommend as she was extremely informative and spoke perfect English. This museum not only holds Faberge pieces, but other works of art. The building itself is incredible! There is a good souvenir shop on site.

Faberge collection. It's wrong to say this is a museum it is in fact a private collection never the less it is an amazing palace with yet another magnificent staircase of marble. We joined a tour at 4 pm with an English speaking guide who was excellent. To see the 9 eggs and all the other pieces in the collection was a delight. It is another must.

Absolutely worth visiting - incredible history. We visited between Christmas and New Years Eve which was perfect time as not very busy.It's unfortunate that there are very few English tours during the day, but we hired the audio in English and tagged along on the Russian tour as you couldn't wander unescorted and we didn't want to come back after 6pm.The museum itself is just off Nevisky Prospect, it's quite an unassuming building from the outside so look hard to find it.On the inside, wow!! Gorgeous palace building, well laid out and looked after. I don't recommend earring high heels as they make you wear little plastic booties over your shoes which was very difficult for one lady in our group.It's beautiful and reasonably priced (although there was quite a large deposit required for audio which is returned at the end).Lovely afternoon dreaming of which egg we wanted to take home :-)

Incredible Eggs - and more!!!. A must do if in St Petersburg - go after 6pm (before then it's guided prebooked tour groups) its cheap to get in - even to "rent" the guide book - and welcomes kids. You need to wear shoe covers which you collect at the cloak room, and there are lockers for rucksacks and bags etc...Amazing to see the Imperial Eggs close up and we spent lots of time in this room, with no rush, but there's so much else to see too....

Incredible!. Wow, what an amazing place this is, we didn't go on guided tour but arrived at 630pm and stayed until it closed at 9pm ( you can turn up from 6pm onwards only if you are not on guided tour). You must have the audio guide which is easy to use and gives fascinating information on the exhibits, particularly the faberge eggs. The museum setting , a renovated palace is truly spectacular, and the contents , all in different opulent rooms , just mind blowing. The highlight of course are the nine faberge eggs, beautifully displayed in glass boxes and you are able to get so close to them to see how exquisite they truly are. They are truly breathtaking. This place, which is privately owned and only opened a couple of years ago , is , quite literally, an absolute treasure .

The eggs are the stars. The Faberge eggs were stunning, though there are more on display in Moscow. The eggs given by Tsar Nicolai as Easter presents to various relatives were the best, touching and poignant given what became of the Romanovs shortly afterwards.The other displays were an anticlimax, though the insight they gave into the business end of the Faberge brand was fascinating.

Amazing and beautiful. It was just like going back in history! At the beginning I was a bit sceptic about going there with my wife, daughter and friends. But once there I was just amazed. There are not only the Faberge eggs to look at but many other things as well. Beautiful building located close to Nevskij street. I recommend you to take a guided tour in order to get the correct information and history behind the objects and eggs.

A pity there are too few English spoken tours each day .... We would have loved to see this museum but there were only Russian spoken tours till late in the afternoon. Hardly any private tours at all ....

Wow!. Fabulous collection, not only of the famous Easter eggs, but much else.....jewellery, tableware and even some Impressionist painting. Well worth spending the hour here to do the tour. Not many tours are in English, and the English audio tour costs extra if you are there during a Russian tour time.

1 hour well spent. Book the Faberge tour with viator.com and you will not be disappointed. We spent 1 hour with a lovely guide who showed us the largest egg collection in the world but she also showed us other Faberge items. Just the palace where the museum is makes it worth while.

Loved it!. This takes a lot longer than you think as it's not all about the eggs - though that was the reason for our visitThey are stunning and the audio is worth paying a few shillings for as it really gives you a thorough story behind each oneLots of other Faberge stuff here too if you are in to that sort of thisng

if you like historic bling !!!then a must. Although this exhibition is my pre booked tours only again it is a must if you want to see a side of Romanov life that truly shows the excesses of the pre soviet lifeThe grantsmanship is wonderful and the setting and presentation of these jewels is world class Especially the few impressionist paintings they have on display with wonderful lighting the canvas as are seen in a new light( excuse the pun) Important to pre book your time slot and do not get upset by the intensive security obviously a must with such priceless objects.The shop is also worth a quick look as there are tourist objects and books which would be difficult to get elsewhereThe restoration of the palace is also a fine setting for this unique display of the faberge art.

Superb Enameled work- Must see!. This museum is also a must, we went after 6pm where you can walk around without a guide, there was a small guide book that you could use (put down a deposit and get it back when you return the book) and this was superb to wander around on your own with. If you wanted to know more about something you could look it up otherwise you could just enjoy the exhibits at your own leisure. The Faberge eggs were just lovely to see and the enameled work was just a superb. Definitely put it on the list of "must see"

The new must see in St Petersburg. Apart form the seven Faberge eggs there are far, far more delights to see. Housed in a spectacular Palace. The trick is to book during the day for and evening visit. This is far cheaper as you do not have to have a guide

One of the largest collections in the world. I had seen works by Faberge before, but this is the largest collection I had ever seen. The Diamond Fund in Moscow is supposed to have a large on as well, but when I went these were not all on display. Lovers of the romantic tales about the Faberge eggs will be delighted by this museum. It is also an amazing testament to the wealth amassed by the Russian Tzars leading up to the revolution that saw them overthrown. Wonderful to see these works in a location tied to their historic context. Also a huge amount of others less know works from the Faberge company. Well worth a visit to this easily assessable museum just off the main downtown street.
Beautiful. Plan a few hours as this museum houses more than the eggsAll lovely but the eggs are something elseSo beautiful I feel privileged to have seen them

Oozing money. The museum is located in a spectacularly renovated and opulent old building that simply screams the obvious wealth needed to purchase and display the largest private collection of these incredible Faberge eggs. The collection includes the original egg commissioned by the Tsar and through subsequent commissions shows the evolution of ever increasing extravagance needed to outdo the previous offering. Well worth a visit.
