Beautiful building with even more beautiful contents!. We toured the Faberge Museum as part of our two days in St. Petersburg. Not only was our guide incredibly friendly, knowledgeable, and well-spoken, but the collection is breathtaking. The eggs are obviously the highlight, but it's also worth it to take a good look at many of the other pieces made by Faberge. I particularly loved the collections of colored enameled pieces. And of course, again, the EGGS. Just absolutely incredible. I could stare at the Lily of the Valley egg for days upon days.

Great works worth a visit. Very nice pieces of arts, so beautiful and worth visiting! However try to check their tour timetable before you go - if you are not Russian speaker, you have two options: 1. Join their daily tour - it's only 2 times a day when I visit this Dec; or you can rent a audio guide and join a Russian speaking tour and listen to your own audio thing all the way... -- this all because you are not allowed to check things on your own here - you have to be part of a tour group no matter you listen to their tour guide or your own audio machine... Tbh it would have only taken my 30 mins to check out the place if I was allowed to wonder around on my own, but because I had to join and stick with the group, I had to be there with the group for 1 hour although it was a Russian speaking tour and I had to listen to my audio machine all the way!!....But still worth a visit and pls do check their time table to avoid any embarrassment like mine..

Faberge Enchants but Cloakroom Attendant Spoils the day. Wonderful building housing some priceless works from Faberge. Excellent guided tour and very informative.Disappointing end tto the tour when we tried to retrieve our coats from the cloakroom. When we checking our 2 coats and 2 hats the cloakroom attendant gave us one card for both sets. When we went to retrieve, she insisted she gave us two cards and would not return my wife's very expensive coat - only my coat but both hates ! She became extremely rude and insluting - appeared to me she had been drinking - and only after intervention by security personnel and threatening to involve the police did we get my wife's coat. VERY embarrassing indeed, and this spoiled what otherwise would have been a nice experience. Be warned and insist on a separate card for your coats.

It's great. This museum is wonderful, the building is beautiful, the collection is awesome, and the way everything is set up is really good.... Better to go after 6 pm, with no guide, but rent the audio guide... Usually they say the tour would take one hour, but if you like it you're gonna spend at least 2 hours.... Now the rouble is down so the tickets were cheap, no more than 7 euros with the audio guide

Beautiful and precious collection in Saint Petersburg. Visiting Faberge Museum I learned the history of a the tradition. In 1885 Tsar Alexander III gave his wife a richly jeweled egg for Easter made by court jeweler Peter Carl Faberge. He made around 50 of the richly jeweled eggs. Mr. Vekselberg , Russia’s richest businessman, bought many things of Faberge collection. Now the 18th-century mansion is housing the museum, it originally belonged to Mr. Shuvalov, a favourite of empress Elizabeth II.This museum and history was new to me and I loved it.

Exquisite pieces in a sumptuous setting. Wonderful museum. The only think I would add is that there are not so many English language tours. The only times that worked before our departure were in Russian but we were permitted to walk around with a Russian group using an English audio guide. It's a great solution. We also left after the Blue Room (eggs) which shortened the tour (probably not allowed by noone objected). After 6.00pm you can tour with an audio guide and your own pace. Before 6.00pm it's tour groups only.

Stunning private museum. This is a relatively small museum which has been privately established and funded by one of the Russian Oligarchs.The marble building was badly deteriorated and has been restored to its former glory as part of the foundations mandate.However it's the vast collection of Faberge material that is the centrepiece of the museum, although there are exhibits of the craftsmanship of other renown Russian jewellers and potters.The piece de resistance are the 14 or so Fabled Faberge eggs which are said to be the largest single collection of this style of jewellery perfection. Our private guide indicated that Faberge produced around 75 eggs up until the revolution in 1917 and a good number of these gave been partly lost or destroyed over the passage of time.Don't miss this exhibit on a trip to St Petersburg-and take a private guide to get the most out of the history of ?Faberge and the individual pieces Unfortunately, photographs of the exhibits are not allowed sour heading a book on the museum shop may be the best way to rember the exquisite collection

Eggcellent!. This gem of a museum is located on a side street facing one of the canals. It is a beautiful building filled with amazing creations! The stories behind the eggs and other masterpieces was fascinating, the guides very knowledgeable and spoke English very well. Of course you will want to make a reservation ahead for the language tour you want.

Wonderful small museum. This is a wonderful small museum displaying an impressive collection of the famous eggs but also of other artwork by Faberge. The location is rather spectacular - a fully renovated palace on the Fontanka river bank. There is an English tour (once a day, I believe) which is well worth it, and not only about eggs... in fact it is a nice expose reflecting the last decades of tsarist Russia.

It's not just eggs.... Amazing creations of the most talented people ...We took a tour and it's not enough time to stare at the incredible items.If I go next time, I'll opt for wandering by myself.Ideal- to do both....

Littlegg-gem. This is a must if you visit St. Petersburg, took away down a little side street on one of the canals you enter a fairytale wonderland of the Faberge delights. All laid out in circular colour rotation with English portable audio to help you along. You will be surprised as to who own what and when.Remember to go after 6-00pm as you can stroll around at your own leisure and not have to go in an organized tour of multi-nationals with a tour guide.
history. history is unreal and clean and you will be in wonder at the class and the beauty of it again you must do it

Beautiful eggs and more!. There is a lot more to see than just the eggs. If you go independently without a guide or group tour it's really good value. You can get into the museum at a fraction of the cost after 6.00 pm. The eggs are stunning and there are other beautiful trinkets on display.

A must see and then die ;-) Thank you, Mr. Vekselberg, for putting these gems on display to the public!. The building, the eggs, the other Fabergé items and one of a kind. Must see for yourself. During the day entry only with pre-ordered tickets, after 6 p.m. free entry.

House of Faberge. The Faberge Museum is not at the original Faberge factory. But the building itself is quite lovely, and houses a beautiful collection of items created by the famous designer. It does require climbing some stairs, and a fair bit of standing, but overall, the museum isn't that big. It's in a lovely location, right on the river, and there is a sweet little gift shop. You can easily do this tour in an hour or so, and it's well worth your time.
Fabulous!. No other word can describe this collection. The entrance fee is the price of a pint! Don't miss this beautifully presented collection.

Worth seeing new museum. This museum is fairly new and offers a vast collection of Faberge objects. You cannot visit the museum on your own during the day, so you have to go with a tour group. When I was there they offered tours in Russian, English and French. My friend and I took the one in French and the guide was very nice and resourceful (the good thing with the French visit is that the group was quite small). The museum has 9 Faberge eggs and the exhibition is centered around them to explain the history of Russia. The exhibition is in a newly renovated palace which adds to the visit. I would go back anytime.

What a privilege. To see the lily of the valley egg up close and the Coronation egg plus so many other wonderments. It was wonderful. Our Faberge guide was so well-informed it was a pleasure to see round this lovely space.

Jewels. Very small but worth seeing museum. Unfortunately it has a gift shop with very beautiful but expensive goods. That is why if your visiting museum with your wife leave your credit card at hotel.

elegant. one of my favorites in st. petersburg, it was beautiful inside and well structured. The Faberge eggs are gorgeous! It was easy to find, they do timed tours. So make sure you plan around the times and they only do English tours certain times a day.

Should be number one on the list. This wonderful ly restored building in itself is amazing but the Fabrege artifacts are stunning. The entire package cannot be equalled. The audio tour (we went especially after 1800 to avoid a tour) is excellent although I admit I was feeling information fatigue but hour two.Please do go. Enjoy. Be amazed.

FABERGE. no more words needed. one of the biggest collections of faberge eggs in the world, several of them being of imperial provenance. and so many other objects from the brand. in a beautiful palace interiour. great guides as well as audioguides.
Beautiful but you do need to be really interested to spend 90 mins doing the whole tour. I would like to have heard more stories and history behind each piece, otherwise each room becomes the same.
A highlight of our trip. My wife fell in love with all the bling in the Faberge Museum. Incredible high end diamond studded eggs beyond the imagination.

Book English tour in advance - worth the detour. You need to book online in advance for one of the daily english tours otherwise go after 6pm as an individual. While I was there is saw lots of tourists turned away as you can only attend as part of a guided tour until 6pm. The imperial eggs are amazing. This museum is the other end of Nevskiy Eve to the other main sites but worth the trip. Don't be fooled into thinking there are imperial Faberge eggs in the Hermitage. They are all here in this museum so this is the only way to see them. There are also another 9 in the Armoury in Moscow. They are displayed much better here in the Faberge Museum so if you had to choose which eggs then I recommend the Faberge Museum. 300RUB. I had trouble paying online with 2 credit cards. The 3rd worked though.

Lovely small museum. Very lovely small museum so it takes only a few hours to see everything. Only one room of Faberge eggs- which are splendid/amazing- but the other art is also very nice. Beautifully restored building. We went in the evening for a self guided tour (with audio guide) so we could proceed at our own pace. Nice gift shop too

Just do it!. Visit for the individuals starts ONLY from 6 pmYou will need 90 mn minimum to visit the placeStunning building and wonderful collection.We didn't rent the audioguide, no real need if you read a little bit before your visit.No photos inside the exhibition roomsCloakroom and toilets. Nice little museum shop.Don't hesitate, just go if you like the beauty

Incredible collection- this is a private museum. You need to get tickets and a guide is highly recommended!. We had an incredible tour of the eggs and other items in this museum- including jewelry, ceramics, and paintings. Get a tour- it is the best way to understand where each piece fits in history and why it was made. It is a beautiful museum and it was not crowded when we were there. No pictures are allowed.

Exquisite!. We felt so fortunate to be taken to this Museum by our private guide. The collection & the stories behind the pieces were very special. It was interesting that our guide had to have made an appointment; our understanding is that you must have a guide & also that you are limited to one hour. Very pleasing hour.

Well Done. We were told this museum has only been open for a year and is a private enterprise. I say "Well Done". The setting is beautiful the tour very professional. Take an hour break from the city in this quiet warm welcoming beautiful environment. However, You'll need to buy a ticket in advance as the tours are limited to 15 people and of course not all tours are in English.
Stunning. We visited in the evening and you avoid the crowds and can comfortably walk around and be amazed at the workmanship of Faberge = not just the famous eggs - silver and enamel work too.

A must see - visit. This was a real eye opener and turned out to be a fantastic visit. Initially disappointed as we had to return a short while later to take an English tour - i am so as we did. The tour guide took us round the major items and explained why they were made, and for whom in a logical sequence that put everything in context and was able to answer our questions. I fear had we just wandered round later we would have just been wowed by the bling. To have so many of the faberge eggs in one place plus all the other items including some amazing paintings - in an immaculately restored palace - and all the collection of a single oligarch is an amazing experience. Do go - and do take the tour - it's an hour well spent. And the gift shop has the classiest pieces in St Petersberg - at reasonable prices.

For Faberge Lovers. Interesting little museum. It has a room full of Faberge eggs. The rest of the rooms are mostly dedicated to Faberge non-eggs creations.If you want to go without joining the guided tour, then the admission time is after 6pm. Try to rent the audio guide. It gives you meaningful information of each box of display.

Must see for all Czarist history buffs. Enfolds an era of Czarist Russia, the little treasures are so intricately designed besides the Faberge eggs, a veritable feast for the eyes! Each egg has an explanation and occasion which is historical. Best buy of eggs, quality wise in St. Petersburg at the Museum shop. NOT TO BE MISSED.

Go After 6pm. The Faberge Museum is very expensive to get in during the day. Mainly because you have to take the guided tour. If you go after 6pm, you can peruse the rooms at your own pace for 600 Rubel or $9. 90 minutes was a decent amount of time in the museum. It would have been 600000 (yes, 5 zeros) to go during the day.There was an option for an audio tour, but you had to give a $30 deposit.There are lots of people complaining about how there are only nine eggs here. But there were only 50 made, so it's a decent collection. And they have the first and last eggs.But Faberge was more than an egg maker. There are so many other beautiful items to see in the museum.One downside was no photos allowed.

Fabulous Faberge. We had an early evening entrance and could walk about on our own; we used the audioguides at our own pace.The palace itself was fabulous-gorgeous staircases, railings, plasterwork and gilt, chandeliers, sculptures and paintings.The exhibits were far more numerous than I expected! Of course there was the beautiful Blue Room with 'the eggs'- it wasn't too crowded and we were able to look right into each individual showcase for the egg and its surprise. Exquisite detail. I think my favourite egg was the "Pink Serpent Easter Egg" clock, but it is very hard to choose just one!Other rooms had displays of hundreds of ornately enamelled items- snuff boxes, combs, opera glasses, spoons, cigarette cases, serving dishes, perfume bottles, silverware, evening bags and more. The detail and the designs were beautiful- lots of art nouveau, which I really enjoy.Make sure you visit the gift shop- it had many items I did not see in any other souvenir shop, and of better quality, that were not exorbitantly priced. Calendars, notepads, cards, books, and jewellery. The replica eggs, and even the egg shaped earrings were quite lovely. Credit cards are accepted too.This was one of our favourite sights during our 2-day tour in St. Petersburg. If you enjoy art treasures, definitely make this unique museum one of your tour stops!

Great little museum.. Fascinating and beautiful displays of the finest of craftsmanship from the period before the Russian Revolution. Well worth a visit. We went after 6pm and rented the electronic audio guide so we were able to go around at our own pace. Only minus is that photos aren't permitted (are they worried that people will copy the designs?!).

Recently Opened Museum that you have to see. This was one of the highlights of St. Petersburg for me because of the collection of Faberge eggs that I had seen pictures of, but now got to see. There are many other Faberge items in the museum and even though I didn't have enough time to see them all, it was worth every minute.
Small but wow !. Feberge eggs & the Tsars personal acutraments , beauty that's hard to conceive , it's a don't miss !

A museum that gives a comprehensive picture of Fabergee work.. The museum has the well known Fabergee eggs but these are overwhelmed by the wide range of skills and craft ship of the enormous collection

History and splendour combined.. Money was no problem for the Romanov Tsar. Faberge created magnificent jewels for the Russian Imperial Court and the series of Faberge Easter Eggs were created as a surprise for the Empress. The collection of Eggs, as well as the other exquisute jewels cannot be missed. Fifty eggs were made, 42 are known to have survived and the largest collections are in this Museum and in Moscow.

Dwelling in the glory of former royal russian life. Without any doubt is the Faberge museum in SPB a very memorable sight and surely worth a visit. The size of the establishment suits visitors of all ages as it's large enough to compensate for its entry price, yet not too overwhelming, making it a pleasureable visit. While there is more to see than the eggs, they definitely make up for the highlight of the museum... I would highly recommend a visit, even if you are not a passionate museum visitor in general.
See it.. Very impressive. Many more things to see other than the eggs! You can't take photos inside. Another excuse for you to buy their souvenir books.

Definitely worth seeing, could be more tourist-friendly. First of all, you have to get plastic "slippers" (really, bags) to cover your feet before going upstairs. Also, you cannot take pictures in any of the exhibit rooms. I believe you are also required to be in a tour group (they have scheduled tours in different languages). Mariya, the guide for my group, was very knowledgeable about Faberge, his works, the times he lived in, his contemporaries, and about the museum and its collections. Worth seeing if you have a couple of hours to do so, but not a must-do, I don't think. Another museum housed in a beautiful palace (Shuvalov Palace).
Faberge museus St Petersburg, Russia. Tremendous display of the beautiful works of Faberge and his contemporaries in this privately owned museum.

Beautiful small museum. This is a small and relatively new museum. It is required that you join a tour to see the museum and these are usually conducted in Russian. There are no signs for the exhibits so although you can walk around on your own once you have joined the tour, it is not possible to know what you are looking at. However if you go to the museum after 6pm, you can rent an audio commentary (a deposit of approximately 2000 roubles is needed) and you can spend as long as you like looking at the exhibits. We were there for 90 minutes and did not manage to see all the exhibits but had to leave to make our restaurant booking. We did of course see the fabulous Faberge exhibits - truly stunning. The museum is located in a beautifully restored house overlooking the Fontanki River. The rooms are a wonderful backdrop for the exhibits.

Smaller, stunning and reasonable. This centrally located museum is a stunning jewel of a site. While it is touted as having 11 of the Faberge eggs, that is only the beginning. The jewels, the boxes, the flatware, the accessories. Each stunning it its complexity. The museum is attractively curated and despite the size of the collection, each piece is available for admiration. At 300 rubles the entry fee in Sept 2015 equated to less that $5.00 USD. Go after 6 pm when the timed tickets have been used. But go. It is so worth it.

Fabulous. We had a great English speaking guide who talked about the history of the collection, although it was busy only small groups were allowed in each room at a time, so you were kept moving. The small shop on the ground floor had very reasonable priced gifts.

WOW. Visited after 6pm and hired an audio guide, you could spend as much or as little time viewing the treasures as you wished. Not at all busy so could stand at the display cases without being hurried along. The workmanship and every detail was spectacular and jaw dropping. Don't forget to look at your surroundings as you walk around the palace is fabulous.As with all the museums and palaces we visited the entry price is half the price you would pay in the UK.The tour books in the museum shops are also very cheap £4 for a fully illustrated book.
Spectacular. An absolute must see museum. The beauty of the jewels is extraordinary and the guides are both very knowledgeable and charming

Night "open time" is better. Beautiful jewel box museum housing several of the Imperail Easter Eggs and other gorgeous works from the house of Faberge and his contemporaries. We came during the day and took an English tour which was good and then returned 2 days after (after 6 pm) for the "open time". This was the only thing I wasn't a huge fan of. The daily tours (the only way to see the collection during the day) are regulated so you have to stay with your group and leave the collection when the tour is finished-- no staying behind to glimpse something you might have missed or really admire. HOWEVER they say you can come back in evenings between 6-9 pm ( you still need to buy another ticket) and then just wander around (with or without a rented audio guide) to your hearts' content. We did not rent the audio guide when we returned so I can't speak to its quality-- but every other audio guide in the city was pretty comprehensive solo I'm guessing that this one would've been as well-- in which case, in hindsight, I wish we had just gone in the evening with the rented guide and had the freedom to take our time admiring these wonderfully intricate creations. Either way though-- the collection is really great and an interesting visit.
Prize visit!. Didn't know what to expect. Fascinating museum. Accessible only with guide provided at the museum. Very knowlegable, interesting tour. Highly recommended.

Even the building is worth the price of admission!. In gorgeous mansion/palace in tourist area of St Petersburg by bridge with statues of 4 horses at corners - worth admission to see the home and its paintings and decor. Only small part had been damaged in war. Faberge eggs were lovely with hidden tiny treasures inside - eg replica of a coronation carriage with window curtains, small frames with photos of Czar Nicholas and family members. Lots of other lovely items made by house of Faberge - clocks, a little box with areas on both ends for stamps and a roller in the middle that would wet the stamps with water under it, jewelry, icon covers, silver tea sets and big bowls, etc, etc. English speaking tours are limited and can only be booked on-line one week ahead of time. An audio guide would be another option and you could go at your own pace and linger over the treasures that interest you. No photos permitted in the display area.
Exquisite!. Exquisite gems of design for royalty - using natural stones and gems. Beautifully displayed and arranged. Strict security, but probably necessary.

fainting and beautiful. Visited as part of a full on two day whirlwind tour of St Petersburg highlights. Loved it. The building alone is worth the entrance price.Exhibits are wonderfully displayed so you can get right up close and marvel at the incredible detail. Access is strictly time controlled so you are not crowded and have just the right amount of time to see everything properly. Our private guide was extremely well informed offering all the background information we needed to perfectly enhance our visit.It's fairly modest in size which means it fits well into this sort of short city tour. I wouldn't have missed it for the world

Impressive . Private museum and a bit over the top security etc. However stars are the collection and Fabergé eggs. History surrounding them and the workmanship and detail is amazing. Not for everybody but I thought whole experience was excellent.

Must go!!!. Finest pieces of jewel I ever saw! Faberge eggs with lots of history and detailed work. Recommend to pay deposit to have audio tour in your language. For sure one MUST GO place in St Petersburg. Search in the net before going to have a good idea of what to expect. Thanks
So So. This is fine but there are much more interesting things to do in St. Petersburg. This does not take a lot of time

Beautiful residence now home to 10 Faberge Eggs.. This formerly privately owned palace is now the home of 10 Faberge eggs as well as many other articles made at the House of Faberge. It is possible to see this place on your own but can be a bit of a challenge to obtain tickets. There are also many beautiful creations made by other artists of the same period and a visit is well worth the effort to get tickets.

If you love the eggs, you will love this museum.. Just opened in November 2013. Thanks to the "Link of Times Cultura-Historical Foundation" established by the Russian oligarch Viktor Vekselberg, it is located in in the erstwhile city palace of the Shuvalov family, which has been beautifully restored and is resplendent in its silk covered walls and gilt ornamentation. Viktor Vekselberg bought the famous Forbes collection of Faberge items, including 9 eggs, which are on display, as well as countless other items from the famous workshops. What I did not like, however, was the way the staff hurried us along, as there were so many people wanting to go through the place.

The ornate beauty of the artifacts in this museum are beautiful. A privately owned and financed museum, it currently hosts 9 of the eggs and their 'surprises' eloquently displayed.This museum only allows groups of about 18 people at a time to move through at a pace that is just enough time to hear the stories of the eggs and other artifacts . Even though my wife and I were on a private tour with SPB, our guide took on another group from SPB at this point to guide them through.The Russian enamel exhibit is also stunning.As mentioned earlier, if you are expecting to languish around the eggs and ponder,, you will be disappointed.After 3 full 10 hour days of touring this was our last stop and It was absolutely worth the visit.

So Beautiful. I have always wanted to see a Faberge Egg. It is a small museum, not sure if you can visit by yourself as all the groups had guides. The EGGS where so beautiful in colour, detail, and design. They also had lots of other items that Faberge had made, which where impressive.

Another Amazing Museum. The Faberge museum has a nice collection of Faberge eggs as well as a large collection of jewelry and other works done by Carl Faberge. All in a nice building by the 16 balls bridge. Very informative tour and the museum highlights the genius of this amazing jeweller.

Beautiful collection with an informative tour. Loved the Faberge Museum. They have two English tours a day at a very inexpensive price. The building, a restored palace is beautiful. The tour was about an hour and our guide was very enthusiastic and informative. The imperial eggs are stunning. There are other collections of Faberge designed jewelry as well. Must see in St. Petersburg.
No Photographs, please!. Smaller than expected with not many Faberge Eggs. Very tight security. Makes you feel like the KGB is in every room. Other places in St. Petersburg much better!

Fabulous Collection - Unhelpful Staff. We arrived and the tour was in Russian. The English one was 2 hours wait.We were offered a audio in English and instructed to press the number of the room for the information.The audio only described the room and not it's contents.We stayed with the tour, somewhat disappointing.We finished the tour and expressed our disappointment.We were THEN told we needed to press 12 in each room for the contents.Would have been better to by told that at the start.Staff were not concerned at all.

Could not believe the beauty of some of the exhibits here.. This is a fantastic museum to visit if you are in a small group and with a guide. The story behind the Faberge Egg is fascinating. The eggs themselves are very beautiful. The Russian enamel exhibition was also stunning.

Cramped entrance, over-managed tours during the day. With these two caveats - the entrance foyer is too small and the museum's guides harry the individual tour guides around by the minute (and there are only stairs to the shop and cloaks), this is still well worth visiting.Yes there are only nine eggs and you only get about 2 minutes tops to look at each one but taken overall there is a large amount of exquisite craftsmanship on show. If you go after 6pm you can evidently travel around at your own pace.Disabled? There is a lift up to the first floor level where the exhibition rooms are but it is tucked away and your tour guide will be likely to press on without waiting for you. On our tour we had nearly as long an amount of time allocated to standing in the shop downstairs as going around the gorgeous rooms. The shop has some good stuff, particularly while the exchange rate is at the present (9/15) levels. Good museum guide book.

Well Worth a Visit. This is a private museum and we visited after 6:00pm - after the cruise ship crowd have left. It is jaw-dropping.The reason to visit are the nine Imperial Faberge Eggs. This is the next largest display after the Kremlin Armoury (10), only here, the Eggs are displayed properly.The Eggs are in individual cases with their 'surprise' next to the Egg. The excellent audio guide describes every minute detail which just takes your breath away. It provides a great insight into how each Egg was made and where each Egg is in the timeline of all the Eggs. Incidentally, the first Imperial Egg is here.And the price? 300 Roubles - about £3.50.

Fabulous Faberge!. We took a private tour to this wonderful museum and arrived for a well planned slot - no crushes of tourists here - our group comprised around 12-15 people so we were all able to get up close and study the intricate and amazing jewel eggs.

Disappointing. This museum is advertised as having the largest collection of Faberge in the world, and therefore I was expecting to see so much more of the work of the great man. Just nine eggs and some other works padded out by other works of Russian masters. All in all a small collection placed sparsely in the many rooms.The palace is beautiful though

Worth Seeing. Even tho we were all but "museum-ed out" by the time my family arrived at Faberge, we were all really glad we stayed the course and went in-it is excellent. My kids were all keen to see the eggs-they were truly much more amazing to scrutinize up close and personal than I had expected! In a city full of amazing sights, the Faberge museum was a favorite among several of my children. It isnt too large-so its "doable- and it is beautifully organized. If u are at all interested in the famous eggs, you will definiely want to visit!

MORE THAN FABERGE. When I told my friend I was going to Russia, he said, "So you're doing the ABC tour?" I asked, "What's that? He said, "Another Beautiful Church!" Well, it could also be called the ABP tour--Another Beautiful Palace! This museum is housed in ABP. It's best features are the Faberge collection, including a number of eggs. It turns out that it is not just items made by Faberge, but also other Russian companies who made decorative items. I would have preferred just the Faberge items. Also, I would have greatly appreciated photos of missing items from the egg collection, if available. In addition, take the non-Faberge items out and add a small theatre with a film showing how the eggs open or their moving parts working.

Looking at fancy, jeweled eggs-if this is your thing, go for it!. This is a highlight for most people but I couldn't wait to leave. However, Hubby was enthralled so I sat on a bench and people-watched. Much more interesting.

over the top faberge experience. shuvalov palace has been restored in such a good way.
and the faberge collection is over the top.
yet one also has to mention the other parts of the collection, cause they are as interesting. russian artist all in all.
fantastic.
such friendly staff, too.
the youtube-chanel of the museum is worth a look, too.
Magnificent Creations!. What a treat to get such a close look at these fabulous pieces - Faberge was a genius to be able to come up with such tiny creations.
Guys,my wife got me to go and it was fine.. Even for a guy,this was fun....lots of fancy jewelry,not just the eggs...about a one hour deal..then go eat dinner.

Faberge Museum. Our visit had been organised through our Seabourn Cruise. Our guide was very knowledgeable about the history of Faberge's work and life and how the Museum had been set up. The exhibits were exquisite -- the craftsmanship is unbelievable - the mixture of materials used was amazing-gold,silver and many precious stones. Well worth the entrance fee.

A beautiful museum. The Faberge eggs are amazing. It is hard to imagine how small some of the pieces are. Especially the prizes inside the eggs.The detail and jewels are beyond gorgeous. There were so many paintings, jewels, decorations it was hard to take it all in. One of my favorite places in St. Petersburg and on my trip.

Don't Miss the Faberge Museum. The Faberge Museum in St. Petersburg was not on our original itinerary and we made sure to add it to our schedule. This was handled through our excellent tour company (see our review: Guide Guru, headed by Natalia). We had a guided tour through the magnificent mansion on the waterway and had the opportunity to see so many of the fabled "Faberge Eggs" and other pieces of exceptional jewelry. We also enjoyed the small gift shop where we actually purchased a replica golden "Coronation Egg" for a more modest price and of better quality than available elsewhere, including the Hermitage Museum gift shop and our cruise ship. We strongly advise you to make sure that you do not miss this new and very special museum, even if an additional small fee is involved for admission and guided tour!
Wonderful. Not to be missed. This is a small museum, but full of beautiful pieces very well displayed. The 9 Fabergé eggs are extraordinary but so are many other objects on view in the other rooms.
Faberge Museum. visit this place only is you are into Faberge eggs. located on the canal, easy access. not crowded as other attractions within the city. entrance not free.

Go after 18.00 hrs.. We were told by our Russian guide that if we wanted to see this museum at our own pace we should go after the guided tours are finished at 6.00 pm, otherwise you are rushed through by a Russian-speaking guide. Then museum is magnificent with a wonderful selection of Faberge eggs. Despite the notice at the start indicating photography without flash was allowed there are many other notices indicating no photography - and this is, in fact, the case - you are told very firmly "no photography".Other Faberge items are displayed in abundance, and there is extensive displays of silver and gold items. The museum closes at 20.00 hrs- or is it 21.00-m, not clear .Two hours is needed to do this justice.
A Fabulous Collection. Brand new museum in an old small palace on the river. Guided by a guides- worth viewing- About 50 minutes. Besides the eggs there is art and silverware etc.

Wow!!!!. Firstly my advice is if you want to spend time in the museum then go from 6pm. Then you can take an audio tour at your own pace. We had to have a guide in a large group and the tour lasted only an hour. There were so many pieces I didn't get to see because of this. It's a stunning building and the Faberge eggs and other artefacts are unbelievably intricate and outstanding. Warm inside so leave your coats etc in the cloakroom. You wear booties over your shoes which is so sensible. Faberge was so immensely intelligent in his designs that what you get to see in that collection, you would never see anywhere else in the world. Have fun!

Over the Top Artistry. I had seen some touring Faberge exhibits in the states and was very excited to see this museum - I was not disappointed. The collection chronicles all the Faberge works - which are varied and extensive. Of course, seeing some of the eggs is a highlight but it is hard not to be blown away with the variety, detail and over the top artistry of what Faberge produced for the Russian Tsar's and dignitaries. Nicely done museum that we thoroughly enjoyed.

Not to be Missed!. A wonderful setting for nine Faberge Eggs and other Russian art.Plan your visit to either get there early in the morning or in late afternoon when you can go with an audio guide. From about 11am on, there is a waiting time because the size of the group is limited and must go with a guide. These restrictions actually make your visit more enjoyable as there are no tour groups of the cruise ships with 20 or 30 people in them.The Shuvalov Palace which houses the Faberge Museum was designed specifically to show off the eggs. At the same time, it has less gilt than most of the palaces on display to tourists. It's a great design, and if you go to see the Faberge eggs in the Kremlin, you will appreciate this display even more.
Stunning. The beauty of the exhibits has to be seen to.be believed.The palace is beautiful too.Faberge was a genius.

Stunning!. We went to the new Faberge Museum as part of a tour with SPB Tours in St Petersburg. Seeing some of the Imperial Faberge eggs that the Czar had ordered for his Czarina was just incredible. The workmanship is outstanding. Definitely worth seeing if you are in St Petersburg.

Amazing, finally I have seen some of the imperial eggs in person.. A very new and privately owned museum. Just the imperial eggs is worth the visit (its a childhood dream coming true), even though they have a lot of other jewelry from Faberge. To get access to the museum you need to book a tour. Be aware that its only a few ones runned in English during the day, so book in advance or at the start at the day.

Highlight of holiday. Visited the newly renovated Faberge Museum. Had a guided tour by an excellent speaking English guide.Amazing to see the Easter eggs which Emperor Nicholas gave to his wife andmother, including the first one and the last he had made before he wasexecuted.

Faberge Eggs and more. A new museum, the building and decor are lovely on there own. The silver and other decor was also nice. But its all about the Eggs, each a unique masterpiece. Too bad you cant take pix - about which they are very serious (but you can take pix on the grand staircase). Also the gift shop has high quality reproductions, priced accordingly.

Faberge Museum. These beautiful eggs are not to be missed! So interesting to hear history of each egg, and to learn what has happened to them since the Revolution.. Each one is so unique and amazing. So many other displays are also there. Gifts, dishes, silver, etc

Vising the Faberge Museum...... The Faberge Museum was part of our ALLA tour. It had very recently opened so it was a treat to visit a brand new museum. It was a beautiful converted palace. We had to put on booties to walk through. We saw the original Faberge eggs as well as other amazing Faberge creations. The exhibit is small and easily visited in about 90 minutes.

Faberge was a Genius. Beautifully curated. The collection of eggs is beyond stunning. The rest of the Faberge collection is. Mind blowing. I could have spent a whole day here. Beautiful building and well cared for. Do. To miss this when in Saint Petersburg

well worth the visit. This smallish museum contains beautiful Faberge eggs. Each one is different from the other, and they are all delicate and intricate. There are other rooms in the museum as well, but the eggs are the highlight.

Great value for your roubles. We did an 11am canal tour and got off right outside the Faberge museum at 12.30 so walked In and got tickets for 3:40pm the same day for only 300 roubles (AU6.50) for a guided English tour. As it turned out this was exceptional value for money. The tour was an hour long and the guide's knowledge was phenomenal. They book groups of 15 for each time slot so you are in small groups which is good as you have to gather around the various glass showcases as they are explained. No photos are allowed inside of the items on display but you get to see a great collection of items in silver, jade and various other precious materials in addition to the spectacular and intricate Faberge eggs and other Faberge items. This tour represents excellent value for money. You can visit this museum without the guide after 6pm to 8.45pm, but as it's so cheap why would you!

Fantastic, breath-taking. A small but very amazing museum, situated in Shuvalov's Palace on the Fontanka Embankment. The excursion is possible with audio-guide and within a group. Duration is 1 hour. No walking alone is permitted. The group is limited. The biggest and the best collection of Faberge works is collected there. Besides Faberge's Eggs there are also other works and even paintings within the walls of very beautiful palace. Unfortunately you cannot take photos there, but it's a must-see place in St.Petersburg.

A must see museum!. My favorite museum of St. Petersburg. Although only two years old, its a beautiful museum with thirteen faberge eggs. You must put on shoe coverings to enter and no pictures allowed. One hour of grand beauty.

Small museum. Great attraction!. Even being a small museum they have great pieces and the tour took about 1 hour. If you can, wait for a guided tour once they talk about the history behind each piece. In Aug'15 an adult entry ticket is 300 rublos. Worth every penny.

A must visit. This small compact museum was full of unique pieces from Faberge and his contemporaries. The highlight were of course the Easter eggs, but the silver pieces, decorative, and accessories were all fabulous as well. In addition to jewelry and finely crafted wares, there were one of a kind religious icons as well as masterpiece paintings. Well worth the price of entry.

Amazing to see. They don't let you take pictures which is a shame but you will have those pictures in your memory. It was amazing to see so many of the famous eggs and to learn the history behind each one. Highly recommended!

Dazzling items on display and beautiful building. You must book in on a guided tour. The tour took 45 minutes to an hour. The young lady that led the tour was exceedingly knowledgeable. The extensive private collection has many of the most significant of the Faberge eggs, all dazzling. The collection also included many other Faberge items all showing exquisite craftsmanship. The groups are small enough to allow you to examine the items on display in each of the glass cabinets and ask the guide any questions you want.

Spectacular . A must see! The eggs are breathtaking but so is the building. I was a bit disappointed I had to wait until 6pm to get in because before the it was guided tours only. Also disappointing you can't take photos.
Magnificent collection. This is a great collection of Faberge art and has only been opened to tourists fairly recently. It demonstrates the evolution and range of Faberge's creative genius

Not to be missed. The quality and scope of work that is here to be seen takes your breath away. And the building, restored especially to take this collection, is worth a visit in its own right.A reluctant husband was spellbound. I just wish that we had had twice the time to pore over this beautiful collection. A wonderful use of an oligarch's wealth.

Another piece of exquisite Imperial family history. Located in a beautifully refurbished building just a short walk off of Nefsky Prospect the museum is easily accessible by independent tourists after 6 PM; prior to that only groups are allowed. Entrance fee is currently 300 rubles. It contains a collection of Fabergé eggs and imperial dinnerware, snuff boxes, cigarette case and various impressive odds and ends of the imperial family. Audio guide rental at 150 rubles is highly recommended for if one wishes to spend a few hours listening to the description of each piece, although I would suppose that the majority of the visitors come to see the eggs, of which there is one less that the Kremlin museums collection in Moscow. However I would hazard a guess that the Kremlin collection, as I recall, is of the more ornate eggs.

A little museum with a great reputation. It is all about undiluted talent here. The museum isn't huge and you are not allowed to take photos but there are a fair number of exhibits. Until 1800 hours it is tours only but after you can be independant and explore in your own time. Given it is often open till 2100 it is nice to do before a meal out for instance. The level of detail in the exhibits is incredible so get up close and if you need glasses don't be vain and put them on to fully appreciate the amazing close up details ;)

Favorite museum in St. Petersburg. The museum itself is lovely in a lovely part of the city. Very sophisticated. The visitors are controlled and so you never feel crowded. You are allowed to move at a nice pace. Incredible exhibit of the famous eggs but there are other nice things to see there as well.

Small but Exquisite Collection of Faberge Eggs with Surprises. Impressive display of 9 (yes only 9) Imperial Faberge Eggs. Before going, I didn't know that they all came with surprises inside (like a flower or another egg). The surprises are on display too. There's an audio tour that tells the history of each Egg - who commissioned it, who received it as a gift and of course details about its design.TIPS: 1. They are open late (until 8:45pm), after other top attractions close. So, plan to go here last. 2. You can easily see the Eggs in 30-45 minutes with the audio tour. The rest of the collection is other works by Faberge like cigarette cases. Allow 1-2 hours to really see these items or just 30 minutes to check out this section out quickly, which is what we did.3. The gift shop has a very nice collection of souvenir Faberge Egg pendants with surprises inside. About US$25. I bought one for myself (love it and get compliments) and wish I would have also got a few as gifts.

Almost incredibly rude. We bought the Petersburg Card partly because it supposedly included an admission to the Faberge Museum - but, when we got there, mid afternoon, the shop-girl in attendance just about spat in our faces: "read your guide!" - so we read the fine print in our guide, and found that the Petersburg Card is only good here after 18:00!Frankly, a museum that treats visitors this way doesn't deserve to have any.

Recently opened museum in renovated palace. This was the last museum we visited with TJ Travel and it was amazing, a small space compared with the others, displays not overloaded and Victoria excelled again in her talk. I was pleased with the variety, having see Queen's family Fabergé pieces at Buckingham Palace. Didn't know that the name was bought by an American business man and the family business is now St Petersburg collection.
Well worth a visit. Not a huge museum but packed full of the most beautiful examples of faberge's work and of course, the exquisite eggs created for the Romanov family. Thoroughly enjoyed it.
A wonderful hour. Expect 9 eggs and a good explanation of the last Romanov. You may not take pctures, so be prepared to buy a book if you want to share.

One of the most interesting museums in the world. I'm not sure what made the Faberge Museum so special, but I found it impossible not be amazed at how intricate the work was, the story behind each of the eggs, and how many other items were produced. A great amount of information was provided, and everything is presented in a very straight forward way. Highly recommended.
Best museum ever.... Incredible to see the Faberge eggs and learn about their history. Our guide arranged a tour early in the morning so no crowds. An absolute must see on a trip to St Petersburg.

I wanted to buy an egg after this. The eggs are amazing. My only exposure to Faberge was from a James Bond movie.
Here, you can see the first and last eggs made for the royal family. The exquisite detail is simply amazing.

More than eggs. This museum has the first and last Faberge eggs as well as a few in between. It also has collections of jewelry, cigarette boxes, porcelain, icons, etc. limited numbers of visitors are allowed in a room at a time so everyone has a good view of the collections. The displays are well laid out and the lighting is perfect to bring out the best of the works.

Wow! Amazing.. While I am not a lover of Faberge eggs. I will say that this museum is incredible. An expansive selection of eggs of all shapes and sizes! Incredible detail in all of them. A must stop.

Best Musuem in St. Petersburg. This was one of the better museum's our family has visited in years. Very expensive admission but worth the price. Our guide was extremely knowledgeable and explained every piece for which we had a question. Very stuffy formal entrance and gruff staff but typical for Russia. Well worth the visit.

Fabrge Museum..a real delight. The Faberge museum in St Peters burg was a real delight. We came to know so many facts about the history of the Faberge eggs. then to see the actual Faberge eggs displayed was so good. I did not know that each Faberge egg has a surprise inside it ... particularly delighted with the replica of the royal horse carriage inside the egg.The other perts of the faberge collection were also interesting. Dont miss this part of the tour in St Petersburg.
Has great pieces. Worth the visit. Holds the already famous eggs and many other item from Russian culture, like clothes, jewellery, paintings and so on.
nice. unique,that is the only word which describes this museumthose colourful desigens they make and some even have figures inside them

You got to be interested. This is a private museum and if you like, or are interested in the eggs, you won't be disappointed. However, there is only one room that displays the eggs. The remainder of the museum holds other collectables from the tsars era through to present day.This is a guided tour so you need to make sure that you book into a time slot that suits your language or you will need to pay for the audio guide. Not a bad thing, but the guide is on a timetable so there is no lingering on this tour. Unfortunately you can't just meander through the museum and listen to everything the audio guide has to say. You are ushered by security guards to keep up with your group. Besides that, if you are interested in the eggs and the history then its well worth the visit.

Dissapointed. UPFRONT ADMISSION - we didn't actually get into the museum.... here's why:We went to the Faberge museum 4 times to try to get in, we had a range of explanations as to why we couldn't get in, but eventually, on the fourth attempt it was then explained that children under 7 years old were not permitted and that they were only taking guided groups before 6pm.Clearly they cannot make rules and then break them, but our daughter is 9 months old, and was carried in a harness by my wife on her chest, and she was firmly asleep, she would have done no damage whatsoever, yet a 7 year old.... We all know that even the best behaved 7 year olds could get a touch over excited! What a bizarre age to chose.
BEAUTIFUL PIECES. This is a private museum which houses the Czarinas Fabergeeggs. They are unbelievable. The silver pieces, boxes and art are worth a visit.

Treasures of all types, not just Faberge Eggs!. A nice way to spend a few hours on a bad weather. So many fine treasures from a bygone era!! More of St Petersburgs amazing collections of treasures!!!!

Beauty of workmanship . What a lovely museum beautiful display is a historic setting. The 1 hour wasn't enough time to do the display justice , but our informative English speaking guide ensured we hit the high spots. Well worth the visit

Nice but to long . The museum itself is gorgeous. The rooms are ornate and as I say simply gorgeous. The collection obviously is sublime. My only issue is that you cannot walk around alone and must join a tour. You can get headphones for an English commentary but the guides speak russian. It makes it long as you are forced to see what the guide wants you to see. If you stray security are quickly in your face so you really are forced to stay with the guide. Not ideal.However it is well worth a visit and as I say the works are magnificent. Faberge insisted on perfection and that is evident in all the pieces. Stunning.

Surprise of Faberge Eggs. Located in an elegant palace, Faberge Museum is a private museum about Faberge company - but we really are interested in Faberge eggs. Exhibition is great although the tour guide was as personal as a cold robot. At least we learned the history of Faberge eggs and learned that they are really much more complex and fascinating that we actually thought.
Fantastic precious works. Amazing to visit and to see first hand seven of the famous Faberge eggs , plus other precious jewellery.You are unable to visit unless you have a tour group booked
magnificent. the collection is huge and the charm is endless. if you are visiting on your own, go at 6 PM as before that it's for guided tours

A memorable experience. The new Faberge museum in St. Petersburg is very special. A large collection of 4000 items (mostly but not totally all Feberge), the focal point are the nine eggs made for the Family of Nicholas II. They are breathtaking. The museum takes only a limited number of people at a time. It is centrally located in St. Petersburg.

Well worth the visit. Used a professional tour guide to go here while on cruise. The museum is very nice and exhibits much more than just the famous eggs, and many of these pieces itself are grand. However only a few eggs (but they are really special) and overall not much more than collection of pieces from the history of the company. Worth a visit but wish it was more interactive. I really got a feeling here of an emphasis of a world of privilege and how different it is than the rest of us.

breathtaking. those things take your breath away they are so exquisite. the audio guide was very good although you have to keep a 2000 rouble deposit for each. there are not many eggs, just one room but it was beautiful. the detail in those eggs was unbelievable.

A Superb museum. It was my wife who insisted we go to see this museum. I had no prior knowledge of it. We took the English guided tour at 4:40 pm. I didn't honestly expect to witness all this fine art and jewellery made by Faberge in the nineteenth and twentieth centuries. the collection is amazing, including 9 easter eggs he made dor the emperors and many other various productions. the halls where the artwork is displayed are tastefully decorated with fine paintings. our guide was very good and knowledgeable. I would love to spend more time at this famous museum. highly recommended.
Amazing!. Amazing Easter eggs, I came here only for these! Amazing jewelry workes, what a history! Shop was nice.

More than just the eggs.. A private museum showing the collection of one of the Russian Oligarchs. He purchased Malcom Forbes collection. But it's more that just the eggs, it contains hundreds of items from Imperial Russia. Well run and well organized. Recommended.
Jaw dropping. Do not miss this museum! An amazing collection which will make you gasp. Go after 6, it stays open until 9 and miss all the crowds. You will be able to see exhibits easily.
Wonderful works. My wife and I had an excellent visit to the museum. The visit was with it just to see the eggs. Highly recommend
Greatest Collection of Faberge Eggs in the World. Once owned by Malcolm Forbes, the collection of Faberge eggs was returned to the museum in 2004. The craftsmanship is unmatched!

Must see museum. We visited in the evening and it is must museums! After the whole day it was nice quite place. All eggs and another things are so nice, so prefect, I realy enjoyed it also with 2 kids (13 and 11 years). Without kids, I will sure stay longer, I would recomend to plan ca 1,5+ hours, a lot of nice things to see there.

Very interesting. We popped in just sa the english speaking tour ended, but we followed the next tour (Russian speaking).I did'nt understand a word but was still enthroled.Top tip pay a visit first to book an english speaking tour if you cant understand the local language.

More Sparkles Here Than Just the Faberge Eggs. I saw many of the Faberge eggs in this collection years ago when Malcolm Forbes owned them and had them on display (maybe at the Corcoran n in D.C.?), but this expanded version in a magnificent old palace is a real treat. The eggs are simply incredible, and the other manifestations of Faberge's artistry and skill are wonderful. The tours that are mandatory here are a bit too long/ too comprehensive, but the museum merits serious consideration.

A must-see in St. Petersburg. We visited in the evening as must museums, being state run, are closed at 5:00. What an experience! The eggs are stunning and are displayed in perfectly clear units making it feel like there is nothing between you and the egg. No pictures allowed and don't even try b/c there are guards everywhere. Just buy a book from the gift shop when you leave. Do the audio tour so you can hear the history of each egg- it will really enhance your experience. The other rooms are glorious too. Be sure to walk through them all. Beautiful, clean, well laid-out. Highly recommend!

Great Audio guide explanation of the eggs adds so much to the experience. My husband and I visited the museum after 6:00 PM. (Visit before 6:00 PM and you're either part of a tour with a museum-provided guide in Russian only or your private guide must have a special license to guide there. After 6:00 PM, you're able to rent an English-language (or whatever language) audio guide for the eggs and go at your own pace. The room at the top of the stairs displays the fourteen eggs that are the centerpiece of the collection. (Only the Kremlin Armory has a larger collection.) The explanation for each egg is nice: enough technique detail so visitors can appreciate the artistry and enough history so we also understand the special story of each egg. If you want more detail, there are additional audio guide numbers you can play. There is also a guide number that starts an audio guide description of each room. Under normal circumstances, the palace is so beautiful, people would visit even if the rooms were empty! Ornate rooms filled with Faberge's beautiful work is almost too much for the eye to absorb.The central egg room is surrounded by at least eight other rooms filled with cases of Faberge frames, cigarette cases, desk clocks, and more. The display is organized by color to help make sense of the huge collection. There is no audio guide narration for these items -- or at least -- we never could figure out the numbering system. However, we carried around a book, on loan from the museum during our visit, that did identify every single object in the collection. This included some limited details but the materials, technique, and date are always provided.Note: Like many Russian destination in old buildings with old floors, you'll be required to put paper booties over your regular shoes. My husband wears American size 11 shoes and he was wearing bulky walking shoes so there were times when he had to struggle to fit the bootie over his shoes. I don't know if those bootie-required museums keep a few super-sized shoe covers on hand or let people visit in their socks.

Decadent Company's Treasure. Their guided tour is so fast that you can barely look at the Faberge Eggs and the security officers try to push you forward. Looks like they don't want you there. Don't recommend.

Faberge. This exhibition is in a lovely private house. As well as the Faberge eggs there is an interesting collection of silver and some other beautiful objects such as snuff boxes. The eggs are in their own room, each in a seperate glass cube so that you can walk right round them.Admission is restricted so the museum is very uncrowded. We were in a guided party of about 12 and there were no other visitors at that time.Our time in each room was however limited and when we attempted to retrace our steps to revisit a room, the attendants chased us out!

Outstanding w/TJ Tours. A must see and Maria, our guide with TJ Tours, gave us the best tour. You make reservations for specific times, and we almost had the museum to ourselves. Photos are not permitted.

Very good. We really enjoyed this museum. Went after six so we didn't need a guided tour but do take plenty of roubles to pay deposit for the audio guide which you do need. Very organised and trouble free. The exhibits are wonderful.

Dazzling Museum. We visited in mid-July of 2015. We heard about the 9 Faberge Imperial Easter Eggs in this museum. The collection includes the very first Egg and the last Egg and the last Coronation Egg (Nicholas II). What I didn't expect was how beautifully they would be displayed. After visiting the Armory Chamber and seeing how poorly lit and cramped their Imperial Eggs were my expectations were not high. Different story here. Each egg has its own clear case so you can see all 4 sides. And the lighting is LED which heightens the experience. Also in the museum are beautiful collections of cigarette cases, snuff boxes, clocks, furniture, wine and punch bowl sets, etc. It goes on and on. What you will not see is anything plain. Everything is embellished almost beyond belief. Even the thermometer had jewels on it! The rooms themselves are something to see. Designed along the lines of Catherine's Palace and Peterhof Palace, only smaller dimensions, nothing is ignored. If you are on a cruise (as we were) and they offer a tour here (ours was $50) I would say you could do it on your own ($5) as we did. As long as you can get there. The location is 1 block off of Nevsky Prospect and a couple of blocks past the giant shopping mall Gostinny Dvor. The museum is on the Fontanka Canal. It is a central location. They give 1 English tour a day but other tours are in Russian. We hooked up with a Russian tour and used the Audio-guide which 2 people can share. It was not a problem. You cannot walk through the museum without a tour before 6PM. At that time you can enter and walk around freely. Go online and reserve tickets in advance because they are limited. There are free lockers to check coats and bags. The museum has only been open less than 2 years so it has not gotten the publicity of more established attractions. But don't be fooled if you have not heard of it. If you have the time put this very high on your list. DO NOT MISS THIS.

Blown away by the artistry. This is a small museum where the building itself is one of the masterpieces. They have a collection of Carl Faberge's famous eggs - about eight of them. Apparently the only other place in Russia with more (nine) is in the Kremlin Armory. You'll be blown away by the artistry and intricacy of the treasures on display here in various rooms. The Faberge house was responsible for a huge range of jewellery, trinkets, gold and silversmithing. Only escorted group tours are available during the day, but head down at 6pm when it opens to individuals and buy a ticket. You need to put shoe covers on in the cloak room and then just wander around the rooms. You can buy some audio commentary too if you like. Some, but not all the signs, are in English.Lovers of fine art shouldn't miss this.
WHAT A COLLECTION. Not only is the collection spectacular but so are the palace rooms where the pieces are housed. Enjoyed the guided tour given by the museum of the history behind Faberge.

Not a lot of eggs!. This is a nice place and must if you really wanted to see the original eggs. What I did not like is that they only had a few eggs. However, there is the only place where you can see the most original eggs in one place.

Astounding and exquisite Faberge masterpieces.. Small museum with the most Faberge eggs you will likely ever see. Also has many non-egg masterpieces by Faberge and his workers. Absolutely exquisite masterpieces.
New museum. A new museum. Had talk the previous evening on the boat about Faberge and where the eggs have ended up. The items were excellently displayed and the guide was very informative.

Small museum but extensive collection. Along with the famous eggs, they have rooms of jewelry, china, silverware and a very good display of masters paintings. You can do this one in about an hour - recommend a guide.

An Interestin Place to Visit. I went in order to be polite to the people we were with. Well this turned out to be one of the highlights of our trip! The history of the Faberge Eggs and their relationship to the Romanovs is quite interesting and informative. The eggs and their little secrets are revealed and well worth the trip. I'm glad I was being polite!
Faberge museum - a real gem. Creations of unparalled beauty and craftsmenship...I was sorry I didn't purchase a replica of a Faberge egg as a pendant...they had a nicer selection here.
A must. A must for everyone who visits St. Petersburg. After the Hermitage the museum that muet be visited. This says everything. Note the opening hours
A bit boring. Not what I expected. A lot if the eggs were nit on display, so quite a few empty display cabinets. Found this all a bit boring.
A must see. Truly amusing what an artistic genius were the artisans. The miniature paintings on the cigarette boxes and the fine detail on all the pieces was extraordinary.

Eggs, eggs, eggs. The Faberge museum is one of our favorite places to visit. As the name implies the best part is the faberge jewlery. The stars are of course the 9 eggs on display and they are certainly impressive. We also liked the many different enamel pieces with their vibrant colour. The security is very tight there so you have to stay within your group otherwise the guard comes over and tell you off. There are also some silver pieces but those are relatively mundane. Focus on the eggs!

An absolute 'MUST' when in St Petersburg. It is a relatively small museum but you could spend HOURS here! Especially if you hear all about the Royal Eggs and see the craftsmanship - so incredible! I prefer this to the Gold & Diamond Rooms at the Hermitage, plus you don't need a curator. They don't allow you to take photos inside the museum so be aware. Definitely don't miss it!

A must see. Truly stunning. I am so pleased that we booked this tour in English as not only were the eggs truly spectacular but the history and stories behind them fascinating also.. Very well organised museum with a lot of other beautiful pieces apart from the eggs even if they are the stars. An hour extremely well spent

The Faberge Museum- a trip to the past. This museum has the largest collection of Faberge eggs. The detail and craftsmanship of the eggs is exquisite. Our guide provided us with the detailed history of each egg, which made it a more personal experience for me. Sadly, no photography is allowed.

"The love for one’s craftsmanship…". This is what it is about! As many gifted men, Karl Faberge was polishing his knowledge during 25 years while volunteering at the Hermitage’s jewelry restoration unit before he started making his own items. What you are invited to see is the result of his love and dedication to the art of jewelry making! However, with time possibly the most experienced in this art have become… the guards of the museum, who often prevent others to ‘look into the very core of the issue’ but this is just to avoid copying : )))

fantastic artcraft. the decorated eggs and the inside "surpeises" maid annually for the tzar are wonderful exhibits of design, craft and imagination. many other exhibits made by Faberge studio, like small decorated boxes, ornaments, jewlery are so delicate that the eye cannot stop looking and admiring the exhibits. 2 hours of pure fun including the story behind each item.
Jewel memory. it´s a small museum, but all the pieces are incredible! Ask for the audio guide to understand the history of each eggs and pieces of jewelry.

Simply stunning!!!. We went to the museum at about 7pm on Saturday (there are no guided tours after 6pm, and you can just walk around and look at the famous Fabergé eggs). I was not expecting anything magnificent but I was simply BLOWN AWAY. The craftsmanship, the exquisite details, the artistry. You have to remind yourself that these eggs were made in the XIX – beginning of XX century, which pretty much puts to shame all the jewellery houses of the modern age, which gave up, it seems, on doing anything so exquisite and beautiful. Simply sunning. None of the photos I took could make the eggs justice. You have to see them.I recommend the audio guide, which offers quite a detailed commentary about each of the eggs and other objects currently on show in the museum.The museum is located in the Shuvalov Palace, which in turn is also one of the most amazing houses in Saint Petersburg, restored to its former glory. For a long time visits to the museum were by private appointments only, so I urge you to go and see these breathtaking objects of art now they are open to public. I cannot wait to see them again!

Faberge Museum. This is my Favorite Museum... I would have to say! It was a very peaceful tour , Svetlana was so well versed in all that the museum had to offer we were spoiled! Svetlana didnt miss a beat! She gave us so much back history on the art / Eggs we were very satified. I really appreciate all of the history how do you remeber all of this information Sventana? Thank Goodness she does it made for a great day! Venue is very clean & cool and well organized Gift shop had the best Faberge egg pendants!

Exquisite craftsmanship. This was the place I least wanted to go on our tour but I am so glad we did. hubbie was just pleased to be visiting a place that wasn't absolutely packed with people. Our Alla tour guide told the story behind every Imperial egg and I was fascinated. We also picked up a couple of other tourists who tagged along after our group so entranced were they by our guides expert commentary. If we hadn't had a guide to take us around some of the magic would have been lost. Do yourself a favour and get the most out of trip to Russia and book a tour with Alla.

Go after 6pm. During the day there are tours and you have to join an organized tour which is a little long and too detailed, but after 6pm you can walk freely at your own pace. The displays are impressive and especially this palace- hidden in what looks like an ordinary building.

Amazing Eggs!. Truly master pieces, such great craftsmanship and detail to the little things that made Karl Faberge a favorite...the museum houses more that the imperials eggs but also great many other pieces......

Not To Miss!. This is a relatively new Museum in SPB. Its beautifully put together, and the love and the rubles lavished show.We added it to our Deluxe tour with SPB Tours after I did some internet research, for a very small additionality. I expected to visit in the evening discounted hours. But SPB took us first thing in the morning when the Museum was practically empty.Bliss.The displays are exquisite. There is no other adjective. Or maybe there are too many adjectives- tending towards hyperbole and extreme fawning!So do fawn on those decadent eggs while you are there. And on all the other trifles that spelt wealth and position in earlier times in Europe.The only cloud on all the bejewelled linings were the KGB style guards everywhere. Decidedly a throw back to Soviet times.One general tip for all Museums in Russia- dont carry big bags or coats so you avoid wasting time in cloakroom queues. We were a large family group of 14 and this save4d a lot of valuable time.And another- a guide is invaluable. But if you have read up on things apriori- savour your deeper knowledge without raining on the hardworking guides parade!' Just my two bit!!Faberge eggs- how can seeing such a collection NOT be on your bucket list?
MUST GO. You all must go to Russia and have a Faberge eggand also visit the museum very nice please mark in the link below yes Was this review helpful? Yes to keep supporting this reviews
Carolyn. So very beautiful!!!!THE eggs are beyond beautiful !Make every effort to see this museum!!!!!The museum it self is also beautifulA once in life time experience!

Only if you have a lot of time in your hands. The museum was not bad, but there were no signs in English. St. Petersburg has a lot of museums and palaces. I would not rank this one top 10. If you have enough time in your hands, you may stop by for a brief visit (roughly an hour). You won´t be disappointed, but it is definitely not the best St. Petersburg has to offer.

Советую всем! Anbefaler!!!I advise everyone ,who is interested in art and culture!. It's marvelours!The collection of Faberge's treasure is unique!Very impressive! We took an English guide-excursion. The guide was very professional and competent!

Small but perfectly formed. A recently opened small museum to showcase the best of the faberge collection, the most interesting was of course the faberge eggs. The guide explained how the eggs started as a fairly simple gift but each year they grew in design, novelty and value till the later ones had moving parts and were studded with precious and semi precious jewels. The museum itself is a beautiful building recently renovated and well worth a look at its architecture as well as its contents.
Amazing collection of original fabrege pieces. If you enjoy craftsmanship at its finest, view the small collection of pieces in this little museum.

probably the highlight of my trip to St Petersburg. You certainly see some bling here, and it's some fascinating stuff. The building itself is also really interesting. I think that most visits are part of a tour, which was really interesting, good info, but I did not have enough time to really look at the displays. And if I lagged back from the tour, a security guard shepherded me (nicely) to catch up with the tour. There are times when it it possible to visit the museum and tour around yourself (some evenings from memory). If I did it again, I'd have visited twice, firstly on the tour to get a grounding and I'd buy a book from the museum store and then visit again 'free style' to be able to wander as much as possible. Did the first two, unfortunately didn't have time to return.

you have to go here. make sure to get the audio guide and make sure you know how to use it. there's so much packed into this place. of course the imperial eggs were the highlight. not just beautiful, also amazingly engineered with hidden mechanisms and delightful surprises.

Beautiful craftsmanship but disapponting display. We chose a two-day guided tour of St Petersburg and were looking forward to ths particular museum. The building itself has been beautifully refurbished and is architecturally impressive. We were a bit disappointed with the display of the famous eggs, although each has been beautifully designed and exquisitely crafted. I think we just expected a much larger display. As we had our own very knowledgeable guide, we weren't herded through by the museum staff.

lots of bling. you always hear about the great Faberge eggs and it great to see some in person, and then earn that they did so much more in the big bling area. If you like flashy this is the right place for you.

A not to be missed exhibition. This beautiful collection is only seen by small groups at a time. Our guide gave us an excellent history of each egg which really added to the interest in these outstanding jworks of art.
Fabulous Faberge. Loved this museum. Not just the eggs (though they are exquisite) but all the beautiful work Faberge designed is here for you to see. Was a highlight in my travels.

Even the Romanov's Could Have Bad Taste. The collection at the Faberge Museum is a collection of uber-expensive tat that only shows that the Romanov's deserved what they got during the Bolshevik Revolution. Whilst the mass of Russian workers and peasants went without bread, Czar Nicholas was writing with diamond encrusted pens. What really sticks out in the Faberge Museum is the nasty, unhelpful staff who will bite their heads off rather than help visitors or answer even simple questions. The collection at the museum may be from the Romanov era; but the museum staff definitely from the good, old USSR!

A waste of time.. I did not enjoy my visit to this luxurious museum, which hosts a collection of 9 eggs and precious trinkets from the famous jeweller.The visit must be guided and the comments from the guides are cumbersome, because they merely describe what you can see and that's all. Security staff are numerous and made me feel uneasy.Visit only if you are fascinated by jewellery.

Awesome. The mansion itself has been impeccably restored, and is a joy to visit. Each room detail has been meticulously done, and the collection itself is an added bonus to this great setting. Thanks to Vekselberg for brining this collection to the public in such an awesome setting!

Great Museum to visit. I visited this small but very beautiful museum. They have guided tours in the afternoons. The building itself is an old palace. One of the most beautiful small palaces you can see. Very elegant place with very elegant contents on display. The english tour guide, Maria was excellent as well.

Private museum. It was part of our tour and our guide was very knowledgeable on the Faberge eggs.The building is small but impressive. Besides the eggs, there is pieces of art, and all sorts of knick-knacks. It takes about an hour to see it all.

Eggs and more. A private museum of the famed eggs. And so much more. You don't realize how much Faberge contributed to the world. Loved all the eggs on display, but wished there were more. Incredible!
beautiful. this nice museum collects many of the famous faberge eggs that tsar family used to give to the family during that time of huge splendour. amazing experience
Worth to visit. Good museum. It's a private collection of Faberge. Definately worth to visit and take a guided tour.

Terrible service. Not much to see.. If you are interested to see a few pretty-colored precious fake eggs you can do this on the internet. There is no reason to waste so much time and money by going to this museum. Besides, the customer service is terrible. I visited with a group and we were rushed by museum personnel without being able to see the exhibits we wanted to! This is very simple: the museum employee DID NOT let us see an exhibit while other groups and individuals could see it!
