Also, while photography is not allowed inside the museum (that is fine, it is their right) there was discrimination inside the exhibition space. There was a tourist in shorts who was getting photographs in the presence of an employee. In fact, it seemed that the employee was accompanying the tourist while he was getting pictures! All of us on the group who were watching this, could not believe our eyes. Visit the Imperial Porcelain Factory which is so much more interesting!

Get there early for the English tour. We were lucky to get the english tour. The customer service prior to the guide needs improvement. Confusing as to where to meet prior to the guide and we almost missed the guide.The building itself is beautiful and the exhibits excellent. The guide was very informed of the eggs and art on the walls. The tour is about a hour, well worth the money.

Do not miss - a gem. Amazing restored city palace with exquisite exhibitions. Very well done tours (English 2x daily or pre recorded device). Need to sign up in advance during high season for tours as crowd control is strict. Good service at casse and wardrobe. The collection is private (Forbes collection via Vekselberg family) and has additional rotating exhibits and exchanges. Best restoration of city palace ever - attention to detail and history. Not to be missed. Wow.

The New Faberge Museum St. Petersburg, Russia.. My wife and I visited this museum at 6pm as we didn't want to be a part of a large group.The building has been beautifully restored throughout and has the most wonderful collection of Faberge items and antiques on display. Of course, Security is Top Notch and many items within special glass security housings. Well worth a visit and they have a large selection of books in most languages for purchase which show everything that is on display.
Faberge. This is a small, new museum, but the exhibit is nice, and the building is beautiful. We spent about one hour there which was sufficient. Not overly crowded. Recommend.

Wonderful value - avoid the crowds and visit during the evening. The Faberge Museum is open for individual visits during the evening, from 6.00 pm. There is an audio guide in several languages. We found this time was more relaxed. The display cases and the refurbished palace in which the museum is housed left us with a sense of awe at the sheer wealth of the original owners of the Faberge items. This visit was one of the highlights of our week in St Petersburg. Don't miss it.

Excellent collection. If you want to see the famous Faberge eggs and lots of silver, gold, porcelline artworks, go there! Open for individual visitors (not belonging to group) is from 18:00 till 21:00.

Imperial Easter Eggs & More. I went mainly to see the famed Imperial Easter Eggs. The museum has 9 Imperial Eggs, and 3 others. And they are magnificent. However, there is much more to the museum than the eggs. The owner has amassed a great collection of Faberge. No picture taking is allowed.
Wonderful. An amazing experience that exceeded my expectations. Exquisite objects beautifully displayed. No photography allowed though!

Wonderful specialty museum. Always wanted to see the imperial eggs, and it is definitely worth the visit. No need to purchase the ticket in advance. The museum is not big and can be done in 2 hours. Love the beauty of the eggs so much that we bought 2 from the gifts shop.

Dazzling Display. We went after 6 pm with the audioguides, and were soon lost in time and space. Each at their own pace meandered through the collection, dwelling on whatever took their fancy, and about an hour and a half later, we surfaced out of our private reverie looked at each other and went wow!You can only self guide after 6.00 pm, before that its guided tours only. The english speaking ones run twice daily 12.15 and 16.15, (ish)Just opposite the museum is an English speaking boat tour that leaves at 5.00 pm, and takes 90 mins. The boat tour / self guided museum combination was a good way to spend a few hours.

One of the best collections ever.. This is a wonderful museum with a priceless collection of Faberge pieces. It's more than just the famous Easter eggs that Faberge created for royalty, there are wonderful pieces that reflect the ostentatiousness and quirky personalities of their once wealthy owners. For a man who hates museums, my partner thought this was the best museum he has ever been to.We booked our tickets online a week before for the English tour and I thought it was worth it because the guide points out the intricacies of each item that you may not have noticed.They don't let you take any photos in the exhibit but lockers in the cloakroom are clean and safe. They also require you to put on overshoes which are handed to you in the cloakroom which makes it feel like a hospital trip but an amusing fashion statement.

WOW, the bling. I loved visiting Fabergé. We got there in time for the English speaking tour. The eggs were so beautiful. I wish I could've gone later in the day so I could spend more time, but we had to get to the vodka museum. I also wish I had done more research before I went so I would've known more about each egg in the museum. This was a highlight for me.

Classy Museum. This museum is not large, but it displays a collection of Faberge eggs. These eggs are quite beautiful and the building is definitely worth a visit. We marvelled at the craftsmanship that went into making the eggs and wondered how such treasure could have survived the Second World War.

Jewels fit for a Czar. So - you have so much money you don't know what to do with it - and of course - you buy bejeweled Easter Eggs. Natch. This private (aka expensive) museum is still worth visiting. Our guidebook had it all wrong - so I highly recommend checking their website for the newest directions. At the time we went - as English speakers - we had several choices. There were 2 guided English tours - one at 12:15, another at 4:15 - the down side - they were limited to an hour - and sold out. During the day you can't visit the museum by yourself - so day time - that's your option. If you want to squeeze into a sold out tour - they will let you - for double the normal cost. Not a good idea.Much better option - go after 6:15 - they charge 450 rubles - and you get your own audioguide. You can take as long as you want to stare at the glorious eggs, silver services, and other do-dads - we took about 1.5 hours - and loved, loved, loved it. No crowds, no peeking over other heads. Just us the gems.You will be a much happier camper. Trust me on this!

8 Imperial eggs on display. The history of the imperial eggs is fascinating, but unfortunately most of them do not reside in Russia. Over the years they have been sold off or gifted to royals in other countries. There are only 8 on display in this museum, but there are numerous rooms of other beautiful Faberge objects. You might want to skip this museum if your time in St. Petersburg is limited.

Precious Beauty. There is only one English spoken tour in the afternoon, but if you go after 6 p.m. you can get an English spoken audiotour which is fine and gives you more time to look at those objects you really like. The museum is in a newly renovated palace - beautiful - it is exceptionally beautiful and not too big - just enough to be very impressed but not bored.
Faberge Museum. Very strict- not much to see. Malcolm Forbes collection which was bought by a Russian businessman.Glad to see this

Beautiful items in an attractive setting. We visited this museum after hours through a Celebrity Cruises tour. The items on display are very attractive. They include some work by other jewellers, but not much. There were enough actual eggs on display to satisfy us, though some eggs were missing their interior surprise. There are also several paintings from the period on display. Some of these were notable for being exhibited in a manner that I had not seen before, such that they appeared illuminated from behind; unique and attractive. We had a tour guide that spoke excellent English and had encyclopediac knowledge of the principal items. I have seen a traveling Faberge exhibit come to Montreal not long ago; this museum had more items than that exhibit.

Fabulous Faberge. Very privileged to be able to visit this attraction. It is only open to private groups during the day time and to the general public in the evenings when there are apparently queues to enter. Our private group visited one morning and only one other small group were there at the same time. To see the iconic Faberge collection was a highlight of the day. A must see!

Absolutely Beautiful. This is a petite and doable museum where you will not suffer from being overwhelmed and can just enjoy being dazzled. Private museum owned by one of Russia's oligarchs. A must see.

faberge museum. It was awesome but could not take pictures, BOO wish I had some pictures for my album of it. It also was not very crowded when we got there as it was late in the day which was really nice too.

Treasure House. Located in Shuvalovsky Palace. A treasure Jouse of Faberge Imperial Easter eggs, jewellery, silver and gold items from around early 20th century. Some other jewellers who worked with Faberge are also represented. Wonderful collection in a wonderful "small" palace. Not open Fridays. Do no that've to book on a tour. Can go at 6pm, hire an audio and take your time. Top museum in St Petersburg.

Eggs. Faberge and his eggs. What can one say about the incredible workmanship, the jewels, the history? I am so grateful we had our tour; it wasn't on the itinerary but Viking took us because of our interest. I would go again if I had the chance. It is a must see.

A wonderful tour. The Faberge eggs on display here were once owned by Malcolm Forbes. I wish we had been allowed to photograph them as they were exquisite. Each egg had a treasure inside, a guilded carriage or a picture. The gems and detail on the outside was a feast for the eyes.

Worth seeing!. The palace and collection of Faberge eggs and other exquisite items are well worth a visit. We were only allotted about 45 minutes to view it all ( staffs decision)- That is not enough time. Need at least 2 hours. Gift shop is nice but hustled out of there too. Guards not friendly, they need to lighten up. After all, we were there only to admire the treasures .There were only a few of us in attendance that evening! Their attitude was uncalled for!

Faberge Eggs. It was amazing to see the very first egg Faberge ever made. So plain and white you would not expect to find the gold hidden inside. I loved this museum and our guide was very knowledgeable. It was a shame we could not take pictures inside, because it is hard to share a memory with fiends and family.

Fascinating Faberge. As this is fairly newly opened it wasn't in our guide book but we were so pleased to have our guide recommend it. The audio guide is well worth the extra and the rooms in themselves are stunning. As well as the breathtaking Faberge work there is a room dedicated to old icons which is worth a visit in itself. We went at 6 pm one evening which was a useful time to fill and then had a lovely if slow meal at Cat a Georgian restaurant round the corner.
Great experience. Loved the eggs but the guards are creapy. They seem like former KGB agents. They really need to lighten up a bit.

Best museum in St. Petersburg. Beautiful,display of famous Faberge especially the beautiful eggs!!
Lovely museum and not crowded because they only let 16 people
in every half an hour!!! I am so happy that it was in my tour
Imwould,not have wanted to miss the opportunity!!

Wonderful experience. We did this tour with Alla tours as a night tour. There are many rooms in this palace that are filled with beautiful things and there are 14 Carl Faberge eggs. You do this tour with radio guides so you can do it at your own pace. There is a room of other Faberge objects that are stunning. There is artwork which is fabulously displayed. You will run out of time to see it all. No photography in here so buy the book as a memento. This is a must do.

9 eggs! + other fabulous works.. could not take any photos of the eggs. This museum has only been open for 1.5 yrs so many taxi drivers are not aware of this museum. They may take you to a very large egg store where they sell eggs, not the faberge ones! Even though our hotel concierge was clear with the driver, he left us off about a mile short of this museum. We hoped in another taxi and he also had no idea where it was. Thankfully we had a map where it was marked with an X and the 2nd driver got us there after a few stops to double check the map.
Amazing. This museum is incredible - the stories of the eggs and who they are for - as well as the other crafted items. you wear booties in here to protect the floor - it's amazing.

June visit. Excellent guide.It is not just the Faberge eggs of the 1880 s and 1890s on show but also a fine collection of silver items including silver trophies for 19th century horse races(shades of Vronski Anna Karenin);beautiful jewellery boxes,paperweights,scissors,all explained in a well informed single tour of the building.

A Must Do. We visited the Armoury Museum while in Moscow so we had been lucky enough to already see some of the Faberge collection.....but this Private Museum takes it to the next level. We did an English speaking tour & the group sizes are limited so you can all hear the explanation of the works & see this wonderful collection without fighting for a spot. Not only are you inside the stunning Shuvalov Palace which is worth seeing in its own right, but the 9 Faberge Eggs are amazing, let alone the remainder of the collection of items made by the Faberge workforce - a must do while in St.Petersburg.

Stunning!. Excellent museum, despite having already spent 8 hours in the Hermitage i went to this museum at 6pm. Some reviews said it was chepaer after 6pm, it isnt but it is quieter so much better to wander around. The fees are reasonable as is the audio guide. Yes you do hage to leave a deposit but you get it back at the end. The audio guide is comprehensive and if you listened to every commentary you would probably be there 3-4 hours. I tended to go and find out the numbers of the descriptions and then go and sit on a bench out by the staircase to listen to it, but then i was knackered after 9-10 hours on my feet!The eggs are amazing, but also there are some paintings, and the gifts from the early 20th century are stunning as well. I am not one for icons but the icon room was actually impressive.Easy to find, just down from the bridge with 4 horses parallel to the river, large banners outside making it visible from the bridge.Nice gift shop, toilets only on ground floor, and you have to wear shoe covers in the main museum area.

has to be seen to be believed. If you've ever wondered what all the fuss is about when people mention Faberge eggs, go and have a look. The workmanship is exquisite - unequalled craftsmanship. One of my favourite trips in St Petersburg!!

Must see collection of Artisanship at its best. Fantastic small museum - excellent examples of turn of the century workmanship - history and stories of the 9 eggs explained as part of guided tour was excellent and put the real stories to the history of these eggs. The private palace itself is very tasteful in decoration and the other collections apart from the eggs were also interesting. The Foundation collecting and bringing these items back to Russia are doing an amazing job. We pre-booked this trip before we left Australia as entry is limited and only available as part of a tour from what I understand. the rest of the tour included a canal boat ride after being at the museum. This was an enjoyable end to the day.

Excellent. This is an ideal alternative to seeing Faberge work, when it's almost impossible to book on-line tickets to see Faberge in the Hermitage. Nice helpful guide, no photos allowed, but I guess thats for security reasons.

Easter Eggs. This was a last minute tour while here, but well worth it. Loved reading & hearing the history of Faberge. Being able to see 9 originals was breathtaking! Many other beautiful possessions of the Romanovs & Nobility on display as well.

A unique museum. A trip to the Faberge Museum is unlike visiting any other museum. I love diamonds and sparkle - I couldn't take it all in such was the grandeur of this beautiful collection.You must book a tour to see the collection -and it is well worth it. The eggs were in one room and there was barely a word spoken while we were there. These are breathtaking pieces made by craftsmen who were exceptional. Faberge himself used techniques that others have tried to replicate in our modern world and have failed.The other treasures are equally worth viewing, a visual feast of vibrant colour, gems and textures. It's a fairly small museum, easily managed in a couple of hours - and don't be surprised by the size of the men guarding some of the rooms!There's a good shop where you can indulge your Faberge dreams at a more modest price. Only downside is that you can't take pictures anywhere in the building except the stairs as you go in. Shame but I suppose that's how they sell their beautiful books...

Small, but stunning. A perfect little museum holding a stunningly beautiful collection within equally majestic rooms. The audio guide is a must to learn about the individual pieces, their history and provenance.

Incredible artistry and workmanship. Like: It is a building that is small enough to be considered intimate and yet large enough to carry grandeur. Being aware of the content through media articles and photographs is no preparation for the real thing.Dislike: The mean looking guards, natural 'heavies' for a Bond film seem assume that all visitors are going to steal or damage the items and surveillance is very close.
amazing. real treasures, precious pieces, big collection, a lot of stories, in very good conditionEggs, paintings, jewelry, sculpture

Faberge Museum is a Wonder!. Alla Tours recommended visiting the Faberge Museum. I was able to get added to an English Language tour group and for a pittance of 300 Rubles I saw one of the best new museums in St. Petersburg. First you see and hear about each of the 9 Imperial Easter Eggs that Malcolm Forbes sold back to the Russians. These 9 eggs and the 10 that are in the Armory Museum in the Kremlin are all of the 50 or so Imperial Easter Eggs that were made for the Tsar's wife and mother to celebrate Easter. Besides the Eggs there are many rooms of elegant jewels and other items - Well worth a visit.

intriguing private museum. outstanding guides, fabulous collection, unique setting.better to book tickets in advance as numbers of visitors are limited before 6 pm and there are no guided tours after 6 pm
Faberge Outstanding. We did a tour of the new Faberge Museum, the number of people are limited and when their were 5 cruise ships in port, we had TJ Travel do ours and it was awesome.

Faberge Museum Imperial Eggs. I had tried last year to see this museum but could not get tickets. Managed to book a visit through Russian agency and it is a delight to see not only 9 of the Imperial Faberge eggs but also many other items by Faberge
Diamonds are a girl's best friend. Informative and engaging tour guide who hustled, a bit, but was very responsive to our questions about the exquisite works of Faberge. Lovely gift shop, too!

Art History. Be prepare to bend and put on paper shoe covers. You cannot lean on any tables or anything here. No cameras. The history of the eggs are wonderful. If you are into art or the eggs, you will find this as a delightful place. You do climb stairs at the Shuvalov Palace, and there is a gift shop. Our group of seventeen folks had our own tour.

Really nice. There are a number of short tours every day ,some in English so you need to check the times and language to suit you,the tours are only about an hour and a number of Faberge eggs and other works are on display together with some artwork.The guide was super ,excellent experience ,lovely building

Stumble Upon. we decided to set up from her hotel on foot on the first day of our visit to St. Petersburg, and just happened upon the Faberge museum. What a score! This is a small museum with a wonderful collection. Try to fit it in to your schedule in St. Petersburg if you have the time.
Unforgettable. Beautiful faberge eggs. The skill that went into the making of them!. Gold and all different gemstones. Amazing!

Stunning!. One of the newest attractions in a city not lacking in attractions. A wonderful collection of works by Faberge and others. The presentation is excellent. It should soon rank towards the top of the Tripadvisor list of things to do and see in St. Pete.I note that some reviewers say that the staff at the museum could be more helpful. My experience was that the staff was both very helpful and very friendly.

A must see in St.Petersburg. A wonderful collection not only of rare imperial A wonderful collection not only of rare imperial Faberge eggs but of other fabulous Faberge creations in a beautiful renovated St. Petersburg mansion. A must see when you visit St. Pet.

Extravgance. Simply a stunning collection of priceless jewellery. Hard to believe that so much wealth was restricted to so few individuals in those early days of the Baltic. Did you know that Faberge had over 700 artisans working for him?
Interesting visit. Quite a nice short visit. We took a guided tour in English and had no problems. We were able to book in advance on the website
Not the average. Very delicate and exquisite pieces. Oh what the work that would have gone in those eggs. A must see.

Exquisite. Every souvenir shop sells matryoshki and Faberge eggs, so it was good to see the originals the master made - as well as examples of other work of his and his contemporaries. Whilst a free-roaming visit is possible one evening a week, at other times visits are arranged as guided tours. These have to be booked on-line in advance - you cannot buy an advance ticket at the cash desk (I tried!). The tours last an hour, and there are only one or two each day in English.

must visit - plan 2 hours.. .8 rooms packed with beautiful things.... had to go back since did not plan enough time at the first visit.. a truly beautiful location and items displayed.. highty recommend. Do not use St-Petersburg Card... it is a waste of money and most important attraction in St-Petersburg are not included (hermitage, peterhoff palace, Catherine palace, imperial porcelain museum, and many other sites; you will either only recuperate 30% to break even...
Magnificent. A little hard to find it but what an excellent visit.Great jewelry display. The palace itself is really nice

A must!!!! Even if you are not an art lover.. Small but comprehensive museum of the Faberge works and others. You can either join a guided tour or come after 18.00, then you can walk around by yourself. I've found the guided tour to be very contributing to the knowledge regarding the collection. You can't take any pictures from the collection, so I've added some photos of the palace- in which the museum is located. Don't miss it!
For jewlery lovers. Very nice and well curated exhibition on the excecess of the czars.Go after 6 and you will have more time than the otherwise allottted 1 hour.

Stunning. This was one of the best museum experiences we have ever had. There appears to be two English tours each day. Our tour guide was excellent. The building itself is beautiful and worth a visit in itself. The tour lasts about an hour and was very thoughtful.

Amazing place but wouldn't let me take photos. Despite the requirement to go on a Russian speaking tour with English audio guide, the Palace was fantastic and the displays of the Eggs amazing. A great visit that forced us to actually visit the gift shop which is unusual for us.

A 'must-see' in St Petersburg. Only recently opened, but well worth a visit - very well laid out, and spectacular examples of Faberge's best works, in quite opulent surroundings. A much better way to see the famous Faberge eggs than the Armoury in Moscow. One tip, to save money go after 6pm in the evening as an individual (groups not allowed after 6pm, so its less crowded as well).

after 6pm for individual tickets. There are two English tours in the morning :12.103.45But I totally recommend visiting it by yourself with the audio guide (3usd extra plus deposit) or with internet (Wikipedia has a lot of info about the Faberge eggs)

Terrible Public Relations. Cannot enter without paying for a guided tour until after 6pm. Cost 300rub. If you want a headset it is 150rub BUT also 2,000rub cash only deposit. I didn't have the cash. I asked for my entry fee back. No. Given a useless free guide book. Ticket seller refused to get me anyone else to speak with. I approached 17 people with no headsets. They were as angry as me. There were 5 people sharing 2 headsets as they didn't have the cash for more. 18 of us made a pact not to buy anything from the Gift shop. Surely 18 people paying 150rub each would be better than nothing. Why not have visitors hand in their cloak room key as deposit as at eg Russian Museum.

Speedy tour but fabulous. Pre book this visit on line to be guaranteed a place on a tour. There are English tours. Each group is max of 15. The palace is amazing and of course the Faberge exhibits are glorious. It was 300 Rubles per person, money very well spent as it gave an insight to the privileged lifestyle of the uber upper class. The tour we were on was a bit too fast, the guide flew around and due to the nature of the exhibits there was a security guard with the group which dis encouraged loitering!

You should go!. What an insight! Before coming to this museum I did not understand why Fabrege eggs ond other products were so special. It is because of the enamelling procees and the very intricate detailing. Wow! As noted, tours are mandatory before 6 pm. We arrived 1.5 hours before an English tour was available, so we went on a Russian guided tour and rented an audio guide which we listened to instead of the tour guide. It worked very well for us.
Poor signage.... Arrived, got inside, queued for ticket ... to be told nothing available until after 6:00pm. A simple sign near the door would've saved time. Ho hum.

Great place. Sankt Petersburg is famous for its museums. Faberge Museum is one more of them. There are not only eggs but also other pieces of art. For examples my students admired Aivasovski drawings. One can have an excursion in English or German. Staff is extremely professional. If you want to look at it without excusion, you should come late in the evening.

Hidden Gem. Hidden down the side of the Fontanki Bridge. During the day all visits are guided tours, if you would rather look around yourself you can go in late afternoon/evening much cheaper. No photography at all and the free guidebook (in English) has no pictures. Breathtaking .
Off the scale fabulous. A private museum with amazing stuff. Owned by a billionaire. It shows what wealth exists in Russia. It really needs to be seen

Come for the eggs but there is so much more. This museum is only available for independent viewings after 6pm. We visited to see the 9 famous eggs but it has so much more than that. It is housed in a beautifully restored palace with a succession of stunningly decorated rooms containing showcases of religious icons, silverware, enamelled objects, jewellery and of course the eggs. Do take the audio guide which is one of the most comprehensive I have used and enables you to get information about each separate object if you so wish.

Worth the visit!!. The museum is set in a beautiful palace. Initially, I was only really interested in the Eggs, but came away with so much more. The location itself along with the grand staircase and different coloured rooms showed the opulence of the era. The Faberge Eggs are really the highlight, but there is so much more to see including gold and silverware as well artworks. A must see when visiting the city.

Thoroughly enjoyes. This museum is filled with delightful relics of days gone by. There are gorgeously intricate eggs, icons, cigarette cases (loads of these), tea services, goblets, jewelry and so much more. There are 12 rooms that showcase the different items. An index book is provided at entry, but if you want to get the story behind some of the items exhibited purchase the audio tour. There are also various works of art and statues. The palace is beautiful by itself, the great works of art and craftsmanship are but icing on a scrumptious cake. Unfortunately, no cameras are allowed so you take home memories and a nifty index book. Unless you purchase something in the gift shop!

Beautiful!. Very intersting new museum in St. Petersburg. Not only Faberge eggs, but also other exibits of jewelery are incredible. Also, interiors of the palace itself are not inferior in beauty to more famous palaces of St. Petersburg. Guides are good and enthusiastic about the museum. My advise: if you have time, come to the museum twice: first time with a guide, and second time by yourself, after 6 p. m.

Only place to see the first and last eggs. Amazing building and museum. You can see the first of the famous Faberge eggs here, and sadly, the last. Plenty of other amazing jewelry on display. A bit odd to have to visit after 6p, but well worth your time. Maybe the top attraction in St Petersburg, for me.

Incredible, amazing - a highlight of our trip. I'll be honest, I was really only interested in the Faberge eggs - and golly I was not disappointed. The palace they are in is beautiful to behold, and the number of other exhibits on show is mind boggling - OK, it does get repetitive, but it gives you a wonderful flavour of this unique company's creations. You don't have to look at everything, just browse and admire the workmanship. The icons room is particularly breathtaking.Ah, but the eggs - so wonderfully presented, you really can squish your nose up against the glass cases and look at every detail. The English audio guide was excellent, just the right amount of detail and some poignant stories. My teenage daughters loved it, too.Tried a number of times to book tickets ahead of time on the website but I never received the promised code by email that you need to complete the transaction. I was worried we would not get in, but actually it worked out for the best. Arrived on the day and just bought tickets for the evening (cheaper than advance booking online), which means we didn't have to go on a tour. So much better, as English tours are limited. I would highly recommend going it alone at your own pace with the audio guide.All in all, one of the jaw dropping highlights of a trip to a city in which my jaw was almost permanently on the floor.

Fabulous Faberge....... We booked an English tour of the museum which was very good with an excellent guide.However if you don't want a guide you can turn up after 6pm and go round on your own. It is well worth a visit and the beauty of the pieces is amazing.

Worth a visit. The museum is located in a beautiful mansion, very well restored. While there is far too much to see (and a lot is in only Russian, no translation), a stroll in the rooms gives a very good sense of the Fabergé story. Very interesting.

One of St. Petersburg marvels. This small museum is also on of the musts of St. Petersburg. No so well-known but absolutely worth of visiting. After 18 there is no guidance (however, you can rent an audio dvd), even guiding in your own language is not allowed but you can easily ignore guard's note as he speaks only Russian.
New, impressive, but..... There's no information on the displays (you must rent an audio guide), but the exhibition is really fantastic, as well the restored building.

Elegant and perfect. Use a chance to see this wonderful collection! After 1 hour excursion you will desire to stay here for hours to adore every piece of art! Elegant and perfect are the right characteristics of this collection. And also democratic. Gold, diamonds, silver... Yes. BUT also cheaper materials were used for creating perfect masterpieces. Masterpieces, not just jewelry.

Gorgeous..... Fantastic private museum, amazingly restored, with 8 Eggs to view, plus many other artefacts. The guards follow you round though, and you are not allowed to take pictures.... Very ornate. Once again, have to take off coats, cover shoes etc...
Absolutely amazing, don't miss it. The most amazing collection of beautiful faberge eggs, i could have spent a day there.Make sure you buy the Faberge Museum booklet (approx £2)

Impressive . Very impressed with this museum and how it is operated. English tour once a day and it was a very suitable guide with excellent knowledge.The collection they have is just amazing!The place on it is own is one of the most impressive houses I have been too. You are not allowed to take any pictures...

Beutiful!. Worth visiting if you like beutiful things. Those easter eggs are lovely. One minus is the fact, that if you take a guided tour, you won´t have any free time to look at those eggs. When the one hour visit is done it´s over, no going back on your own.

Faberge. It's well worth your time to see not only the preserved pieces made for royalty but also his many pieces made for the common person. But, you must have a guided tour in order to enter. ***No photography inside, but it is still worth it!

Interesting and tastefully done.. It's worth a visit and lasts an hour. This was about right to keep the interest of the younger party members! If you want an English speaking guide it's only at 4.15. If you go after 6 you can pick up an audio guide and do-it-yourself. The exhibits are stunning.

Beauty in miniature!. With DenRus, we got to view the museum before it opened, and were the only ones there! Faberge made so much more than eggs! Amazing examples of the jeweller's art. The palace it is in is spectacular are well. Make sure to check out the rooms the exhibits are in. They are works of art, too!

Nice goldsmithing. Wanted to see some true Russian goldsmith work and we did. Museum has very strict rules how to behave and what to do. It´s understandable because those objects are worth of millions... After 6 pm there is no guided tours anymore but you can look objects by yourselves. Audio guide is a must if you don´t get guided tour. Once a day there is tour in English. There is lots of guards and you are not allowed to take pictures.
A true way to know some about Russians Emperors treasures.. An exceptional exposition of jewelry genius. This is new "must see" place for St. Petersburg guests and residents.

Highly recommended. Definately a place not to be missed - the palace has been so nicely restored that it's a sight of it's own, and then all the gems and breathtaking pieces of incredible craftmanship from the era before the Soviet era.

precision, art and geniality. I visited this museum a few months after opening, and it was not crowded or having to purchase tickets online. The museum staff is extremely friendly and the exhibition indescribable. So much creativity and artistry in making the exhibited objects - fascinating. Romanov dynasty are definitely had more taste of the Habsburg monarchy, and respected and known to pay Faberge geniality. Audio guide that was of great help.

Amazing exhibit items in a beautiful palace, lovely staff. I debated whether to go to the Fabergé museum and am so glad I did. The craftsmanship and creativity are beyond belief. If you look up the internet you might think meh, decorative ornaments, but to see them up close in person is something else. I got the audio guide for an extra 150rubles which I found very useful. Take note that you need to pay a 2000ru refundable depositI for the audio guide. I didn't get the catalogue book that documents every item in the museum (which is free but requires a refundable deposit) so can't comment on its usefulness.The staff here were by far the best I have experienced in St Petersburg. They all had helpful attitudes, from front desk to the gallery staff, and just wanted visitors to get the most out of their visit.Highly recommended. It didn't take me very long to go through, the museum has later hours so it is definitely something you can add to your day after the other museums have shut. The only thing is guided tours end at 5. I missed out but thought the audio guide was good enough.

Faberge Museum - not a ton of eggs. I recommend going after 6 pm when you can go on a self-guided tour. Either rent an audio guide (which, by the way, had an absurd 2000 ruble deposit on the audio device) or they can loan you a guide book. It's a neat collection of Faberge items, but as I mentioned, not that many eggs. The KGB style security was fairly intimidating/annoying though.
Could not visit. I believe you have to book weeks in advance to visit the Faberge museum we could not see it in the two days we were there

Superlative. This is just incredible. Way beyond words...the beauty not only of the fabulous pieces on exhibition but also the stunning palace in which they are housed. The highlight of our trip here.

We really enjoyed the visit!. The Faberge Museum experience was beautiful, informative and memorable. The stunning Faberge eggs are definitely worth seeing not just for the beauty but for their historic relevance and besides the rooms have much more than just the eggs. Beautiful jewelry and little objects for the royal family still contain the energy of the old times. The museum itself is very beautiful, large spacious halls all decorated in their own style are a pleasure to walk in. There is even a hall with paintings which are very beautifully lit, you will be surprised. We did go on tour (before 6PM you can only go as a part of the guided tour group). I think next time I would prefer to go on my own to fully enjoy the pieces and take my time.

Must be seen. A private visit was arranged and we had a tour in two groups of 12, the eggs on display are from the Forbes Collection that was sold for 200 million dollars , and has been added to by the person who owns the collection, who has a lease on the palace that it is in and he restored from his own funds into the amazing setting for the collection.Security is very strict and you do see some wonderful things never seen in the west , the gift shop is a wonder in its self and must be sen and allow lots of room to buy goodies.

Exquisite Faberge. We have visited many museums and art galleries throughout the world but the St Petersburg Faberge Museum took our breath away. The museum building, which was a palace in Tsarist times, has been restored to its former glory by a group of private investors. Many people associate the name "Faberge" with eggs but there are many, many more treasures nicely displayed in the glass cases. The treasures had been retrieved from all over the world. It was not possible to take photographs but the treasures will live on in our memory! The charming guide was very knowledgeable and helpful. Tours are conducted in both Russian and English at separate times. It is advisable to book for the English tours. However, we just turned up at the door and were able to join the next tour. Highly recommended!

Our Special Private Tour. We found this place quite by accident while looking for a french pattisserie.We were priveledged to be shown through the museum by the manager who explained all details for us and was most courteous and presented us with a beautiful copy of the Faberge book which showed all the wonderful jewellery that had been made.

Superb Faberge pieces - shame about the Soviet staff!. The Faberge pieces on display are wonderful and the palace setting is lovely - but the whole experience is spoiled by excessively zealous staff and very poor information in the displays. Go to see the Faberge and go if you want to experience what Russia was like in Soviet times!!

Impressive. this place was such fun, not only because of the collection of Fabergé but also for the charming guide. It is set in a wonderful palace. The location is right on the Dontanka, just few steps off Nevsky Prospect. One can reserve tickets online - probably a good idea if wanting one of the tours in English. The museum is also open at night and one can just wander on ones own.
Beautiful collection. We could see incredible art work from Faberge. I think only in this place there is a complete expotion of this kind of objects.

Very impressive collection but gets repetitive fast. When you see one Faberge egg, you admire its intricacy for a while and conclude it's impressive work. Stunning!. Absolutely worth visiting! Just provided a tour of the place to my tourists and immediately took pride in the collection that represents the most significant example of our cultural heritage.

A highlight of our trip. We were lucky to arrive just an hour before an English-language tour and got the last two places. Had been looking forward to this and was not disappointed. Tour guide was informative and happy to answer questions. Felt a bit intimidated by burly security guard following us round. Had plenty of time and space to see the eggs. Pity not to take photos but the guide book was fairly priced with pictures of most of the eggs. Lovely clean toilets and locker room.

Ab Ovo. My husband and I toured this museum on our last day in St. Petersburg, October 9th 2014, and I wish we'd gone earlier in our stay, so that we could make a second visit. The building is a restored wonder, and The Hermitage Museum could learn a lot from this restoration. As just one example, the window frames are sealed and painted, not cracked, warped and peeling. All the painting and moldings in the building were beautifully presented, along with appropriate furnishings in each room. The restroom and waiting areas were nicely appointed, and it was no hardship to wait for the tour to begin.The tour we joined was for Russian speakers, but we did have the English audio and that helped. The collection of eggs was truly amazing, along with a totally unexpected collection of fabulous paintings, that were only illuminated for as long as the group was in the room, perhaps a total of 3 or 4 minutes. As we left the room, the trailing guard turned off the light, leaving the collection in total darkness. Someone obviously knows the value of this collection and has given it the highest forms of protection with its conservation in mind. Kudos to whoever OK'd the spending of the money for adequate staff and renovation, it was worth it.The only thing I could fault is that there is no book or information available on the fabulous paintings and their painters. When I asked about it at the information desk, the lady seemed quite puzzled as to what I wanted. She referred me to the cashier (who spoke better English) and who was quite indifferent to my request. Pity, as I'll bet I'm not the only person who would like more information about the collection and its building. The Museum is missing an opportunity to educate the masses (and enrich themselves at the same time.) If they spent some money putting together the information I bet they'd see a return on their money almost immediately. However, the gift shop was one of the best we'd found after spending 10 days in St. Petersburg, with a lovely collection of Faberge egg pendants for sale. They had a display of very rare artistic egg pendants (that were far more pricey than the usual pendants) and I'm still kicking myself for not buying a couple of them. A first rate experience, and I highly recommend a visit (or two) to The Faberge Museum.

One of St. Petersburg's finest museums. During my recent visit to St. Petersburg I decided to return to the Faberge Museum. During my previous visit back in June, one had to join a group tour in order to view the Faberge treasures housed in the beautifully restored Shuvalov Palace, however, this has since changed. You can now visit the museum independently, but only after 6 pm! The Faberge Museum is open daily (except Fridays) from 10:00 am to 8:45 pm. The ticket office is open from 9:30 am to 8:15 pm. Admission is 300 Rubles - a bargain! Guided tours are offered from 10:00 am to 4:50 pm in both Russian or English. Duration of the guided tour is about one hour. Individual visitors are admitted from 6:00 pm to 8:45 pm. Hand held audio guides in various languages (including English) are available to rent. I was delighted to have had the opportunity to purchase a ticket and spend a couple of hours browsing the numerous display cases filled with Faberge treasures at my leisure. I would also like to note that the museum also has a gift shop on the ground floor, which offers a selection of souvenirs and books. The shop offers a 170-page Exhibit Index, which I do recommend to those visiting the museum independently. The price is only 150 Rubles.This museum is undoubtedly one of the city's finest museums. It is centrally located and easy to find, being situated on the Fontanka Canal just off Nevsky Prospect.

Incredible!. Even in a city full of of wonderful and beautiful sights and sites, the Faberge Museum stands out. It is worth the trouble to find it[it's in Centre] and the structured tours; you need not wait for the English language one [not so good anyway] and worth a repeat just to linger over the "eggs" and other indescribably beautiful pieces. No one elsewhere at any time has done what the Faberge enterprise did in its heyday. What you miss being here [since it's not] you can pick up on at the Armory Museum in the Kremlin in Moscow. We visited the Faberge a day midweek in mid-autumn and there was a total of just nine in our group. The security folks were OK with us lingering a bit behind the tour [all Russian, except for us]. When we left the Museum we proceeded immediately to the "House of Books" [Dom Knigi] close by on Nevsky Prospek] and purchased several books on the Faberge house - and were primed for the "eggs" and other pieces we saw at the Armory in Moscow. Do not -- Do NOT miss -- the Faberge! As we were leaving I felt like Howard Carter -- "I [have] see[n] the most beautiful things...."

Hidden away but worth a visit. We stumbled by accident on this and came back the next day to do the English tour. It was a beautiful museum and the guide gave a fantastic history and account of the stories behind Faberge. It is a shame you cannot take photos but it was definitely worth the 60 minute tour.

For Faberge Fans. If you are a Faberge Fan this Museum is a must for you. please take in consideration that the visit is only in in guided groups and the English tours are limited. Make sure to reserve the tour in advance and come in the booked time.

Not to be missed. A lovely new museum that was fascinating. Includes the Forbes collection of eggs. Low season meant only 2 people on guided tour. Check hours of English tours in advance, as you have to be with a guide except evening.
good but expensive. a unique place to be, but enterance fee is too high. very interesting but not a must. pieces seem so valuable and original.

Excellent Tour. Amazing tour beautiful pieces and one of my favourite tours in Russia - We actually visited the 10 eggs on display in the Moscow Kremlin Armoury also and was disappointed that there was no information on them - The audio guide in Moscow did not even mention them - Well worth a trip to the Faberge Museum in St Petersburg

A Golden display. Do go in and go on the guided tour. It is well worth the visit. I think you can go later in the evening and listen to a soundtrack, but, worth while going on the tour. Easy to get to. We walked back to our hotel after.
Have to see.. If you hate to walk hours to see treasures of former russian empires, this is the museum for you. So much to see in about one and half hours, so close, so easy.

Exquisite Gem. This museum is exquisite - as well as the famous Faberge Imperial Easter eggs formerly from the Malcolm Forbes collection, the museum contains hundreds of pieces of jewelry, decorative objects and porcelain made by Faberge and his Russian competitors. Amazing. It is like walking in to a treasury and you don't want to go home. The guide was very good and knew her historical facts very well. The only down side was that there was no free time and you had to follow the guide. If you have a chance, do it.

Fabulous Faberge. I had done my research on Tripadvisor re this visit but only picked up that they were closed on Friday on Thursday evening. We visited on Saturday at 0930 when it opened as we had elected to take the Russian tour with the audio guide as other reviewers had mentioned and it worked extremely well. There were only 3 Russians in the group with the two of us and we had time to listen to the audio and examine the Faberge at leisure. The staff were extremely helpful and even the restrooms were well worth a visit. The shop was not expensive (apparently!) and they now have a book on the eggs in English and well worth buying at 700r.Alongside the Hermitage this has to be one of the main reasons to visit St Petersburg.

Outstanding. Privately owned with the largest collection of Faberge eggs. Unbelievable the beauty and art of these eggs. Be sure and get a book explaining the history of these art pieces. Take your time enjoying these pieces. hoto takingis limited.

Faberge Museum. We were told about this in Moscow, didn't know about it prior to this. We didn't go on a tour, and went in the evening. It is small, but we enjoyed looking at the Faberge eggs. The eggs are spectacular, and presented very well. We actually went through twice so we could see the eggs again. The detail is incredible. New museum - don't miss this attraction. The Faberge Museum opened in early 2014. It is housed in a building that used to be the home of a noble person. Truly a superb exhibition of Faberge eggs and ornaments. It is heartening that Russia has at last been able to acquire these 'lost' eggs and put them on display in such beautiful surroundings. It is essential that you join a tour (for security reasons) so it's best to inquire ahead of time to make sure your tour leader speaks your language. It takes about 1-1/2 hours and is well worth seeing. No photographs are allowed but inexpensive books are available and a very good gift shop sells quality imitation items that are much better than the gee-gaw ones available anywhere else - evidently they are made specially for the Museum. The location of the Museum is right beside one of the canals and is close to Nevsky Prospekt.

Spectacular. A block up from the Anichkov bridge on the Fontanka, the Shuvalov Palace has been restored to perfection. Huge collection of russian gold, silver, icons and of course faberge eggs and other faberge items, lots of them. Displays well lit and protected. One darkened room has paintings lit to perfection. Even if you don't swoon over faberge, you should visit for the relaxed atmosphere, the perfectly restored palace rooms, and the wide variety of items you will not likely see anywhere else.

THIS IS A MUST!. It was not so long ago that a visit to St Petersburg, where Gustav Fabergé established his business in 1842, was virtually devoid of anything related to Fabergé. However, that has recentlyl altered. In 2004 Victor Vekselberg purchased what remained of the Forbes Magazine Collection of Fabergé. It is rumoured that he paid just over US$100 million for what included nine Imperial Eggs. He added more Fabergé as well as Russian decorative art and Russian art. Housed in the restored Shuvalov Palace, this is the best collection of Fabergé on permanent display anywhere in the world. If you visit St Petersburg, you simply have to visit here. The Museum opened in 2013 and for a period access was not easy. Indeed, enthusiasts were paying up to Eur 200 to visit. However, booking is now much easier and cheaper. The Eggs (including the Duchess of Marlborough Egg, Resurrection Egg and the two Kelch Eggs - the Hen and the Chanticleer - as well as the Spring Flowers Egg - upon which experts are divided) are displayed in a large room. Another is entirely devoted to Fabergé. The result is stunning, if not overwhelming. Indeed, I visited with experts from the world's leading auction houses and one muttered, 'It's all too much!'. The second largest permanent display of Fabergé is at Houston, Texas. Visit, enjoy and be dazzled.

Petite and pleasing. We were initially a bit worried after reading earlier reviews about rude reception of foreigners, but when we went, the staff were welcoming and helpful. There was a large LCD screen listing tour times, languages and number of tickets left, they keep their groups small. We went in the morning to check the schedule as there was little info on the website, bought tickets for the last afternoon tour, which gave us the rest of the day at the Hermitage.You can go with the audio guide after the tours are finished, but we found that our guide was well informed about the collection and it was very easy (and encouraged) to ask her questions.The intricacy and workmanship of the pieces is phenomenal, and well worth your time, even if you've seen the Kremlin Armoury.Thr art collection at the end of the tour was a lovely surprise, with an impressive state of the art lighting system.

Wonderful display and guides. The only way you can see it is with a guide at a per-scheduled time so work it so you are not disappointed. Guides allow a total understanding and appreciation for the fabulous art and mechanical achievements of these famous pieces. The shop has some nice pieces for reasonable prices.

Highlight of our Russian holiday. One of my reasons for visiting Russia was to see the Faberge eggs here and in the Kremlin Armoury, and this collection was truly magificent. We visited with an English speaking guide, and were accompanied throughout by a huge minder to stop us from lingering , but we didn't feel rushed at all. As well as the eggs there were hundreds of smaller items of enamel work, in a rainbow of colours. They were all displayed and lit to perfection, unlike those in Moscow, and the museum building itself was an architectural gem too. Highly recommended

Great, but a bit disorganized. This museum had an outstanding collection and was worth seeing. However this is not well organized for the English-speaking tourist, as we had to view the collection with a Russian-speaking guide while we listened on the English Audio set. It seemed a bit silly, but that was their rule. Despite this, we still learned a lot and saw an amazing collection of Faberge eggs. They often had a special feature, like a pop up bird that sings inside, or a built in clock. We had no idea the depth of craftsmanship that went into these eggs. Faberge legacy, like the end of the collection of art and the building of churches, all came to a grinding halt in 1917, Bolshevik Revolution. Fortunately, many collectors held onto these amazing pieces, and the collection that is found in St Petersburg is really worth seeing.

Mind boggling. If you like Faberge there's lots of it. The shulavov palace which houses the museum has been renovated and is part of the attraction. It's beautifully done. Each room is spectacular. As to the ;Faberge items...it's sensory overload. Some are famous and gorgeous, others are just gorgeous.

Do Not Miss This Museum!. This Faberge Museum opened in November, 2013, in the former Shuvalov Palace. The Museum building itself is a jewel in white marble. Because of time constraints, we went on a guided tour done in Russian, but if we asked questions, she responded in English. In the Blue Room are the nine imperial Faberge eggs. Wonderful Visit. The only English language tour is at 4:30, but we could not stay around long enough for it to start. We had to move from room to room with the tour guide, but held the receivers up to our ears and wandered around the room looking at what we chose. Worth a visit. Centrally located and you get to see a magnificent collection and a grand buildingOpen till late so can be squeezed in at the end of a day while waiting for canal tour

Don't miss this!!!. Recently opened earlier this year, this Museum is mind blowing. The collection is out of this world with 9 of the 50 eggs on display. A "Gem" of a museum!. Today, after visiting the recently opened Faberge Museum, my eyes actually hurt! Of course, this is in a good way. Between 1885 and 1917, Peter Carl Faberge and his team of 500 artisans, created collectible of detailed, jeweled, fold and silver, enameled intricate "gifts" of arts presented or designed for the monarchs and fashioned Russian citizens. This private museum centered in the center of St. Petersburg Russia is lip octaves at the opulent palace of Count Shualov. Most famously known for his creation of delicate jeweled eggs, Faberge oversaw and created approximately 50 eggs for Russian tsars Alexander III and Nicolas II commissioned eggs for their wives and mothers as Easter gifts.43 survived, 9 were collected by Malcolm Forbes, the American publishing magnate, later to be sold by his estate are now held in St. Petersburg. This is the world's second largest collection of the imperial Easter eggs. Aside, you will use at least 1 1/2 hours to tour this place. You will spellbound by the details of this 19th and early 20th century arts....intricate silver dinner sets and unbelievable enamel works. Remember these were designed by high fashioned, exceedingly wealthy Russians. The setting, which has several flights of brilliant carved marble stairs surrounded by a gorgeous ataircase sits in a restored palace along the Fontanka River. I promise you will not be disappointed!

Fabergé Eggs are back in St. Petersburg!. Nine of the famous Fabergé Easter Eggs are back in St. Petersburg! If you happen to be in St. Petersburg, Russia make sure to include a visit to the fabulous Fabergé Museum. This wonderful museum is located in the beautifully restored Shuvalov Palace, where nine of the famous Fabergé Easter Eggs are the central pieces of the exhibition. The first Easter Egg was commissioned in 1885 by Tsar Alexander III for his wife Maria Feodorovna. The tradition of gifting Easter Eggs spread among the members of the Romanov Dynasty, the rulers of the time, and other kingdoms in Europe. The last Easter Egg was commissioned by Tsar Nicholas II in 1917. The Tsar and his whole family were murdered the same year by the Russian Bolsheviks, who took over the power. The Bolsheviks collected most of the Fabergé eggs, decorative pieces and jewellery available in Russia and sold them throughout the world because they didn’t fit their ideology.The St. Petersburg Fabergé shop produced 65 eggs. It is believed that there are only 57 eggs known to be in existence. Nine of these eggs were part of the Forbes Magazine collection until 2004, when they were bought by Viktor Vekselberg, a Russian billionaire, just before they were going to be auctioned. These nine Easter Eggs are now the most important pieces at the fabulous Fabergé Museum, being the largest Fabergé Easter Egg collection under one roof. The museum has 12 display rooms with 4000 exhibits and more then 1000 pieces from the Fabergé jewellery shop. The Shuvalov Palace is the perfect home for these beautiful eggs, as hey are an important part of St. Petersburg’s history. Their return home bring back happiness and pride to the Russian people.

There were far fewer people in the museum so we really got to see everything at close quarters. Visitors do need to know the deposit for the audio sets is 2000 rubles, per set, in cash. The hire cost of the equipment is reasonable and the entry fee is perfectly acceptable. There did not appear to be guide books for sale prior to the visit, which would have been helpful. There are many miniature eggs, enamelled and jewelled photograph frames, snuff boxes, clocks, travel items, and much, much more. The museum is near the boat trip station on the Fontanka near the Anichkov Bridge (with the 4 horses) on Nevsky Prospect so not difficult to locate. Our Hotel Concierge gave us full details. I my opinion this is now a MUST see in St Petersburg. In fact, maybe the top MUST SEE!

A true gem!. We stumbled across this museum on a side street along a canal. Wow! First it is in a beautiful restored palace with a graciousness of a different time. Nice and interesting museum. My friends and I spent around an hour in this museum. The museum is not very big, but the collection is incredible beautiful.
