The story that takes you from the first egg to the last is truly beautiful. Some of the other items within the museum are also quite amazing, Hundreds of personal items belonging to past members of the royal family. Who knew Fabergé made so many things!If I had to choose of all the sights in St. Petersburg which were my favourite, it would be a close call between this and the Peterhof gardens. If you're lucky enough to be going, enjoy!

Gorgeous museum, but individual tourist-unfriendly. Unpleasant things first, the way this museum operates is a bit weird, but hey, their museum, their rules. You can only go as a part of a tour group until 6 p.m. and only then they let in individual tourists. There are no description underneath the exhibit boxes, you either get an audio guide or a descriptive booklet, but the latter is only in Russian. The price is adequate for what you get. Unfortunately, you can't take any pictures once inside.The museum itself is located in a beautiful building, which itself is a true gem. The floors, walls and ceilings are a spectacle, and you haven't seen the glass stands yet. Everything is decorate, meticulously crafted and really beautiful. Just wow. The gift shop is a good place to buy larger replicas of Faberge eggs, they are superior to the ones sold in many souvenir shops at the same prices. Great museum, would have given it five stars if not so many pet peeves aimed at tourists.

Amazing. We had a private evening tour arranged for ten of us by our DenRus guide. When we arrived we were practically the only ones in the museum and our guide skillfully guided us from one room to the other so we were the only ones viewing the amazing Faberge eggs and other items made by the Faberge family. Only 57 of the 65 eggs are still known to exist and nine of them are in this museum housed in the beautifully restored Shuvalov Palace. The museum has 12 display room, amazingly some of them are air conditioned, and it has a total of more than 4000 exhibits, and more than 1000 of them are from the original Faberge jewelry shop. The really private nature of our tour and our excellent and informative DenRus guide added to our enjoyment of this incredible exhibit. As we were leaving all the tour groups and buses were arriving so try to get an early evening private tour.

WOW. A must when in St Petersburg. Not on tourist guides yet so go as soon you can. It is quiet and gives you an amazing chance to view 9 eggs and a lot more beautiful jewellery and silver by Faberge.

Beautiful with good tour. We arrived during the day to discover we had to wait an hour or so for the next English-speaking tour. No unguided visits were permitted. And I'm pleased we had to be in a tour as you'd miss so much if you were not guided through this exhibition. Each of the eggs had their own story and the guide was excellent in passing on her knowledge. Apart from Faberge, there's so much more to see here, and the beautiful and elegant building was worth the visit alone.

Not to be missed. The building is stunning as is the exhibition.There are 9 eggs on show: the first and last ones made for Tsar Nicholas. There is much more to see and if you are a lover of fine things, then this will surely satisfy your senses.

If you love Faberge eggs, you MUST see these!. Independent travelers can buy same-day tickets between 6-9 pm (no online or advance tickets) to see the dozen or so famous Eggs in this private collection. We arrived at 6:30 pm and had no line. This is the largest collection outside the Armory in Moscow and well worth seeing. Just a couple blocks from Nevsky Prospekt at 21 Fontanka Canal, it's easy to get here from the Metro.

A must see. Opened by a Russian Billionaire a few months ago, it houses original "eggs" and other Faberge memorabilia. The work is beyond description, and houses the collection bought in 04 from Malcolm Forbe's private collection.

Fabulous collection.. Some outstanding works of art by Karl Faberge, including 9 of his most famous eggs. The tour that accompanies your ticket is well worth it, very good English speaker, with amazing facts and figures. A must see.

Amazing. We arrived at the museum only to find you can only visit this attraction after 6pm if you are an individual tourist as the daytime visitors are groups or Russians. The rooms themselves are beautiful and the exhibits well laid out. We were unable to take photos but enjoyed the visit.

All I can say is Wow!. This "museum" just opened in January, so it is not yet on the itineraries of most shipboard or guided tours in St Petersburg. The museum is in a newly renovated, (takes your breath away) palace, and the Forbes collection of FABERGE eggs and other Tsarist artifacts displayed beautifully. Truly a highlight of our trip.

Appalling treatment of customers. We would have loved to see the Fabergé Museum during our trip to St Petersburg but unfortunately, even in the face of stiff competition, this was by far the worst type of customer service we experienced during our holidays - bad enough to put us off the museum altogether. We were told to shut up when we were discussing whether we had enough time to go in (in the reception area of the museum). Apparently listening to a foreign language gave the receptionist a headache. When I (limping after a day of sightseeing) sat down in silence to wait for my friends in the lobby she told me I had to get up and stand in the neighbouring entrance hall, no explanation given. Not to mention that we were paying customers (or hoping to be), this would be shameful behaviour regardless of the circumstances.

Back in the USSR. Surprisingly, this was my 9-year old grandson's favorite of the places we visited in St. Petersburg - but it was mine as well. Brought back to their original home my m(b)illionair Russian Victor Vekselberger who bought the entire Malcomb Forbes collection when it went up for auction, the eggs are the main attraction, but there are many other Fabrege items here. Items, especially the eggs, are very well displayed. We were with a guide but had ample time to view.

Beautiful and stunning Faberge. I was advised to go to the Faberge Museum after 6.00pm because there are fewer people and it is cheaper at this time.
The museum has a stunning range of Farberge items - not just Faberge Eggs. Beautifully displayed and commentated on by the audio guide. This is a must see when visiting St Petersburg.

Impressive. For those who are afficcionate of jewelry, specially Fabergé eggs, this is a must see museum. Is new, installed in a restaured palace and the work is really fantastic. Bad points: entrance fee is high and no pictures are allowed.

The Museum - a Must see. You can miss the Golden or the treasure rooms in Hermitage but do not miss when in town to visit the Faberge Museum - Ex Forbes belongings bought by Victor Vekselberger...Just be aware that you have to be there before 10am, get a ticket for a tours - you may not be able to go in before 6pm as no prior reservation is done, no individual, just on going small groups but what a pleasure.... and also a fabulous renovated palace!.

Fabulous museum. We loved the Faberge museum in St. Petersburg. The palace has been totally renovated to the original style by a wealthy businessman and the Faberge eggs are incredible to see. We liked the palace as the setting for the eggs because it was so intimate and exquisite down to the smallest detail. I highly recommend that you read this wonderful book: Nicholas and Alexandra by Massie. You will learn about how Nicholas gave Alexandra an egg for each Easter celebration. The palace tour guide was exceptional, even though his tour was supposed to be only for Russians. There are English-tours but the museum doesn't seem to have a decent system for alerting the tourist about when they are. The website didn't state the English-tour times; there are no audio guides in English yet; and some tourists arrived with us and were turned away, even though that morning the museum had told them to come back at that time. We decided to tag along with the Russian tour even though we didn't speak a word. The very nice and informed tour guide broke into English at the end to give us some information. There are some good English interpretative signs as well. We just loved this visit!! We wouldn't bring children. It is very much a "don't touch" place.

It is a 'must see'. Arrived at 1020 for the ticket office opening of 1030. First in a queue of about 10. Having read previous reports of the English tour not always happening (we were offered 2.30) even if they say it will we took the first Russian tour (11.30). Although the museum opens at 11 pre booked guided tours may be before you. Stunning collections, layout, lighting-. Bright rooms you did not have to stand looking at one exhibit and could move freely around each room. Although in Russian the Guide did not spend too long on each item so it was not tedious as you could look at the other exhibits. The Guide was quite happy to answer the odd question in English and several Russians also told us about things. No photography. Should have a guide book produced but maybe that will come soon. I would go back again - well worth a fiver (5 Uk pound approx)

Worth the effort for me. This is a private collection, as opposed to a museum run by the state or a company, which might explain why visiting it is not as straightforward as it might be.We arrived at about 10.10 and joined a small queue waiting for the opening time of 10.30. Once inside, we went to the ticket office where we were told the time of the English tour. I was expecting this to be 7pm from what I'd read on the forum, but it was actually 3.30. This was a Saturday, so maybe it varies depending on which day of the week it is; or maybe they just decide on the day - there seems to be no way of finding out in advance. You are asked to arrive 10 minutes early, so you can put covers on your shoes. There is no refund if you buy a ticket and don't turn up. No photos or videos are allowed.Faberge made 50 eggs for the Imperial royal family, and 11 similar eggs for wealthy individuals. This museum has 12 eggs (the largest collection in the world) including 9 Imperial eggs (only the Kremlin has more, with 10). There are quite a few other objects which were originally owned by the Forbes family, many of which were made by Faberge, and show extraordinary work with enamel and gold. There are also some paintings, including a Renoir, and the building itself is pretty impressive.I would not describe this as a "must see". But I've always been fascinated by the Faberge eggs, so it was definitely worth it for me.

A new kid on the cultural block. The recently opened Fabergé Museum has nine imperial Easter eggs and much, much more. Housed in an impeccably restored town mansion, the exhibits comprise several hundred examples of Russian jewellery and silverware, each object more exquisite than the last. We were lucky in our tour guide (booked via our hotel). She was well briefed on the collection and lectured in clear and idiomatic English. The displays are at the cutting edge of museology and no expense appears to have been spared to make a wonderful collection accessible and interesting. Just one word of caution: the museum guide book has not yet been published and the museum shop does not yet even stock postcards of the eggs! There are fridge magnets and copies of the eggs though. These copies were on on sale at 30-40% cheaper than in commercial outlets but you will need to pay in cash since the shop is not yet geared up to accept credit cards

a shambles. Although repeatedly excused to us because the museum 'is newly opened' this place really needs to get its act together. Although in theory there are English language tours on offer, the monoglot ticket office is usually unable to tell you when they are so you can't book them. Taking a Russian tour as non-Russian speakers we were told not to go ahead of the guide so walked through a 90 minute incomprehensible commentary past unlabelled exhibits. There are some very lovely things and also some exquisitely ugly but beautifully crafted items where form and function have lost any connection.

Fantastic museum, but let down by the administration. I recently visited St Petersburg for a long week end (April) and loving Faberge’, I put in my schedule the recently open dedicated Faberge’ Museum.I would like to give 2 different ratings: one high rating for the museum and its treasures but a very low for its management.Placed in the Shuvalov Palace, 21 Naberezhenaya Street, the Faberge’ Museum looks over the Fontanka river and it is easy to find.A notice on the entrance door advises that the ticket office opens at 10.30am with strictly guided tours (max 15 people each) starting at 11am until 7.00pm. There are only few days a week open for visits: Wednesdays, Thursdays, Saturdays and Sundays.From my Internet researches I was aware of a limited number of English speaking tours and that it is not possible to purchase advance tickets. So due to my short time spent in the city, I thought that a ticket for a Russian speaking tour would have been my only choice.No indication of other particular access requirements were indicated in the notice.Once open, people were met by a sort of check point where a lady had the function of deciding who was allowed to purchase a ticket and who was not.I soon discovered that only Russian people were allowed to visit the museum on that day. Everyone non-Russian was categorically refused entrance.I explained that unfortunately I had that day only, being in St Petersburg for a short time (like other tourists in the queue) and that I would have liked to take a Russian tour anyway, still thinking that it was only a matter of language choice.However the museum attendant absolutely and categorically refused admission because I was not Russian.Only after several minutes and discussions, she took out a folder and said that there was a tour for “English” (meaning ‘rest of the world’) the following day at 7pm.Me and the other ‘rest of the world’ explained that unfortunately it was not possible. Some had to leave the same day, some just could not make it and asked politely if it was possible to have a ticket. Even a nice Russian lady in the queue tried to help me with no results, looking a bit embarrassed herself.During this time the attendant kept completely ignoring us and went on speaking in Russian granting access to the local people only.A nice foreign family that was next to me tried everything to explain that they were leaving the same afternoon, that their hotel phoned the previous day and were advised by the museum staff to be there the following morning at the opening time, but the only answer was a clear hostile refusal.At this point this lady started to complain that the “English” take photos and use mobiles when it was clearly forbidden. We eventually understood that the “English-rest of the world” were not accepted for the reason that we all were disrespectful of the museum’s rules.She went on complaining about it without listening us assuring that we would have not taken any photos or used phones. At this point I personally felt really discriminated and even insulted as I was pictured as the stereotype careless tourist.When she finally felt reassured by our promises of respecting the museum rules, she decided that we could entered for the 12pm tour. I grabbed the chance and took a place, before she changed her mind. Unfortunately for the nice family next to me the imposed time, was not possible and sadly had to leave.I bought the ticket and left.I finally managed to start the tour with a mix group of Russians and foreigners. The tour starts from 2 rooms showing over 100s of pieces of Russian silverware fantastically carved dated from the 18th and 19th century. The tour than goes to the main room where the famous Faberge’ eggs are displayed. It was a real treat: Lilies of the Valley Egg, the Coronation Egg, the Bay Tree Egg, the Fifteenth Anniversary Egg, the Renaissance Egg to name only a few. There are 9 major/more refined eggs plus some more ‘simple’ looking but very beautiful none the less. The guide spends times to explain every single one of the Faberge’ eggs leaving enough time to closely observe them in their fantastic details and glory.The following rooms hold 100s of pieces of Faberge’ jewellery items, from clocks, picture frames, tobacco boxes, vanity cases, miniatures jewellery in the form of animals, every day utensils in gold, precious stones or rock crystal (like miniature hot water Russian style boilers/kettle), jade letters openers, stationary items and much more. There is even Faberge’ thermometer with a gold deep blue enamel top/cap.The exhibition finishes with 3 rooms with paintings related to important events in the Russian history and a display of religious Russian silver icons and objects beautifully carved and detailed.The guided tour lasts 1h30-40 minutes.For the Faberge’ fans, this museum is not to be missed. Just Google images of the museum in St Petersburg and you will see official public photos of some of the items displayed and the rooms.The Palace itself is beautiful making a fantastic frame to the collection.However the management of the museum should understand that non Russians tourists should be given an easier and more frequent access.According to my experience with that particular lady, it is my strong feeling that the (low) availability of English speaking tours is not done to help foreigners to understand the explanations, but rather to limit the access to anyone that is non-Russian.To be proud of being part of a great country and its art is understandable. For this reason a more flexible and polite approach should be adopted in making visits more available to anyone (internationally speaking) who love and appreciate such magnificent works of art by Faberge’.Every country in the world have both respectful and rude citizens. However to be blindly discriminated and categorised as an English/rest-of-the-world-disrespectful person is hardly acceptable.The museum at the moment does not have a website and there is no way to know well in advance when an English speaking tour is scheduled. They just say to turn up on the day when they open (as I did) and try your luck.I am aware that some travel agencies have special arrangements therefore if travelling through a specialised operator, it is worth to ask if they can book a visit. While there I noticed a small private group accompanied by a local English speaking guide.Independent travellers could try with a local operator if they want to avoid any surprise.For people who stay in town for more than 2/3 days, they could go to the museum when they open and check for the English guided tours available but no advance booking is possible.The entrance is RUB300 but an agency would charge a lot more.The Faberge’ Museum administration has the freedom to apply any policy of their choice on who, when and how to admit visitors. However in order to avoid misunderstandings and upset people, an official international website should be opened, clearly explaining all the relevant admission information and timetable for a smooth, joyful, trouble free visit.
